column2: " In this district you never know," Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal said yesterday. "I'd be afraid to call it."

The League of Women Voters of New York State urges a "no" vote on Amendment 3, the Fifth Judicial Department, on Nov. 7. We oppose the creation of a costly and unnecessary new appellate and administrative structure for Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The ballot proposal would split the present Second Judicial Department into two parts, thereby dividing the existing appellate caseload and administrative responsibility between the two units.

FREIBURG, West Germany, Oct. 23 -- The two major parties, the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats, were the big gainers in communal elections yesterday in Hesse and Lower Saxony, where about 80 per cent of the eight million voters turned out.

NEWARK, Oct. 23 -- A small but steadily growing illicit market in methadone, the synthetic narcotic used as a substitute to treat hard-drug addicts, has emerged in New Jersey and with rapidly increasing fatal results.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Oct. 14 -- In 1900 France and Spain signed a treaty that established what is now the border between Gabon and Equatorial Guinea. But because the treaty was not explicit enough, a dispute flared recently between the two West African neighbors, and a four-nation commission was formed to settle it.

Peter J. Bridge, who was sent to jail for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about a news article that he wrote for the now defunct Evening News of Newark, describes his life in the Essex County Jail in the following article.

The Continental Telephone Corporation and the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge and form what they claimed would be the nation's second largest telephone company outside the Bell system.
Seven prisoners made a daring and well-planned escape from the Manhattan House of Detention (the Tombs) early yesterday in the first jailbreak from the present building since it was opened in 1941.
Striking employes of REA Express were ordered back to work last night by a Federal judge after the union rejected the company's latest contract offer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Richard J. Sullivan. Alfred E. Johnson. Joseph A. Bosco. Fred B. Burke. John Kramer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 -- There were signs today that Henry A. Kissinger had achieved some success in his five-day effort here toward a settlement of the Vietnam war, but evidently without having reached a conclusive agreement with President Nguyen Van Thieu.

NEWARK, Oct. 23 -- (UPI) -- Senator Clifford P. Case's campaign director said today that he had filed a complaint with the Fair Campaign Practices Committee objecting to billboards that said the Republican Senator favored "forced busing" in New Jersey.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -John Havlicek's 10 points in the final period helped the Boston Celtics pull away from the Philadelphia 76ers for a 105-85 victory today to extend their winning streak to seven games.

ITHACA, N.Y. -- President Nixon now justifies continued United States military involvement in Vietnam in large part by portraying Vietnamese Communist leaders as bloodthirsty fanatics who would order a massive "bloodbath" against their former foes if they were to gain power in South Vietnam -- one which would be even worse than the present daily bloodletting.

BOMBAY, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Esso Eastern, Inc., an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) that has one of the largest private American investments in India, disclosed yesterday that it had offered to sell all its business or 74 per cent of its shares to the Government.
BRASILIA, Oct. 20 -- In the name of common heritage and interests, Brazil plans a new push into Africa.
SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 23 -- The South Korean Cabinet issued three special laws today in preparation for a national referendum to be held next month to change the Constitution.

Detectives have been looking for Ted Gross, the former Youth Services Commissioner, since Friday to serve him with a subpoena to testify in a city investigation of financial irregularities, reliable sources reported yesterday.

No fewer than eight singers were new to their roles at the City Opera performance of "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" Sunday night. Since the company lacks a second Beverly Sills to sing all three heroines, these parts were assigned to separate sopranos -- inevitably destroying the one-woman-in-three premise that Tito Capobianco's willfully pretentious production italicizes ad absurdum.
Investors who have been watching American Telephone in recent weeks may be wondering whether the sleeping giant is about to rise at last.

What the Equity Library Theater has done with Beaumont and Fletcher's "The Maid's Tragedy" is this: They have intelligently coiled inside the frame of the famous old Elizabethan classic an hoisted the play far enough above the boards to make it lifelike, if not alive.
American art dealers are not alone in their unhappiness about the way the Metropolitan Museum of Art is selling some of its treasures. The coin trade here is miffed as well.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A committee of state officials who regulate public utilities said today that the late-payment charges imposed by most gas and electric companies were too high.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Mexico initiated a campaign by nonnuclear countries today to induce France and China to join in United Nations disarmament negotiations.

WAYNE, N.J., Oct. 23 -- At 5 o'clock one recent morning, Ken Boyle, Ken Nelson and Walter Jauch were in the parking lot of the Willow Brook Racquet Club doing calisthenics. They were not health freaks.

The Columbia Broadcasting System reported last night that Mr. Kissinger and President Thieu were in "complete agreement" in principle on a ceasefire plan, but that there were four areas of major difficulties.
The final day's play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's metropolitan championships began at the New York Hilton yesterday afternoon with 70 teams competing in the Swiss team event.
WISCASSET, Me., Oct. 23 ((AP) -- The nuclear reactor at the Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company plant here was put into operation for the first time at 4:55 A.M. today.
Black families are being asked to refrain from going to work or school, and from shopping and traveling on Monday, Nov. 6, in observance of the fourth annual Black Solidarity Day.

In black slit skirt, and wearing an expression of exhaustive experience, Geraldine Fitzgerald sings "Pirate Jenny." For the first time within my memory, a singer who does not have a German accept is able to strike exactly the right quaver for this sorrowful and abrasive song.
" It's very passe to mind if other women have the same dress." said Adolfo in a very firm tone of voice.

The patriotic aspects of the Veterans Day holiday, providing an opportunity for the muster of armed contingents, posed a security problem yesterday for President Nixon's motorcade tour of Westchester that clearly lacked a standard solution.

BOHEMIA, L.I., Oct. 23 -President Nixon, telescoping virtually all of his New York metropolitan area campaigning into a single day's swing through Westchester County and Long Island, sounded familiar campaign themes and called for pluralities greater than those he received in the 1968 election.

Of all of the late William Fitts Ryan's stanchest advisers and supporters, nobody knew more or cared more about the causes for which he fought than his wife, Priscilla, now the Liberal party's candidate to succeed him in the Twentieth Congressional District.

The recent rash of robberies of elementary school teachers in their classrooms comes on top of a series of cowardly and despicable assaults, including the brutal mugging of a teacher during a field trip with her class in Prospect Park. These outrages emphasize the urgency of rethinking and revamping school security.

" Ecucci" (Italian for "Here we are") proclaims the marquee outside the little sportswear shop at 1162 Madison Avenue. Although much of the stock is from Italy, the owner, Georgina Brody, is Hungarian.

YONKERS, Oct. 23 -- Baseball's Gene Michael and Whitey Ford, golf's Lew (Buck) Worsham, hockey's Gilles Villemure and horsemen from as far away as Australia, California and Florida were among the overflow crowd of 2,500 at the second matinee of the Old Glory Horse Standardbred Sale at Yonkers Raceway today.

A gifted violinist named Gunars Larsens made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall late Sunday afternoon, and the countries in his background would almost make a United Nations quorum: of Latvian descent, he was born in Belgium, grew up in Australia and now lives in Switzerland.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, the President of Uganda, was admitted to a hospital today, and his doctors ordered him to take "a complete rest," the Uganda radio announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -Lord Cromer, the British Ambassador, called on the United States today to exercise leadership in the next major round of international trade negotiations, tentatively set to begin late in 1973.

The City Health Department charged 22 more restaurants and other food establishments last week with "serious Health Code violations" and threatened to close them unless they were cleaned up in time for final inspections in three weeks.

The Socialist party-Democratic Socialist Federation deplored yesterday the resignation of one of its three co-chairmen, Michael Harrington, and reaffirmed its preference for George, McGovern's Democratic candidacy against President Nixon.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it was calling its $1.40 convertible preferred stock for redemption.
Reports that Arab League mediators have achieved agreement on a plan for peace and ultimate unity between the two Yemens will be greeted with relief tinged with substantial skepticism.

C. W. Post became the latest college in the metropolitan area to make drastic cuts in its intercollegiate athletic program as officials at the Brookville, L.I., school last week ordered large budget cuts in all departments -educational and extracurricular.

" Katy-did, she-did" sings out the tireless musician of the insect world. And now, high-speed movies, synchronized millisecond for millisecond with tape recordings of the melodious insect, disclose how the complicated courtship song is sung.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23 -- Fourteen armed men stole more than 100 weapons early today in a raid on a base of the part-time Ulster Defense Regiment in Lurgan, about 20 miles west of Belfast.

When Henry L. Diamond, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, neared the end yesterday of his bicycle ride across the state to promote the $1.15-billion environmental bond issue, he issued a statement that said "Based on the reception we have received I am convinced that the issue is going to carry the day on Nov. 7."
Twelve art works whose total worth is estimated at more than $500,000 were stolen last Thursday night from the Caramoor Center of Music and the Arts in Katonah, N. Y.

PEKING, Oct. 23 (Agence France-Presse) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed head of state of Cambodia, said here today that Le Duc Tho had told him a week ago that "the most difficult and delicate" part of the Vietnam peace talks still remained to be held.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- For the second time this month a mass-circulation weekly has denounced Senator George McGovern for linking the Soviet emigration tax to the prospects of United States-Soviet trade.
School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has set Nov. 15 as the deadline for all city principals to submit plans for teacher and student safety in their schools.

Because hindsight is so much better than foresight, Eddie Bell and Earlie Thomas will be the featured players at next Monday's gathering of the New York Jets "First and 10" luncheon at the Playboy Club. Yesterday's guests were Dave Herman, guard, and John Little, defensive tackle.

FREEPORT, L.I. -- When Rori Gordon was 5 years old she began helping her parents, Richard and Ancil Gordon, in the family's fairly extensive flower gardens at 95 West Third Street. There was nothing unusual about this. A lot of children take a fling at planting bulbs or seeds and watching them grow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- "Since Mr. Nixon has been President, rape is up 22 per cent," an announcer observes in a matter-of-fact tone. "Since Mr. Nixon has been President, aggravated assault is up 25 per cent."

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner last night agreed to white parents' demands and reassigned 31 black pupils whose enrollment at John Wilson Junior High School 211 in Brooklyn touched off a three-day sit-in there last week.

The plan of the Great Western United Corporation to sell its beet-sugar subsidiary and to retire its $1.88 preferred stock should meet with the approval of shareholders, according to Nathan K. Mendelsohn, owner of 37,200 preferred shares.

SOUTH STRAFFORD, Vt. -- A hunter's moon washed the hills and valleys of Vermont the previous evening, and in the morning frosty leaves crunched underfoot and icicles gleamed on the rocks of trout streams.

Pan American World Airways Inc. reported third-quarter net earnings of $20-million, or 50 cents a share, yesterday, down more than 20 per cent from the $25.5-million, or 64 cents, it earned in the third quarter of 1971.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23 -- What began as a madcap political medicine show in Washington -- "the snake oil special," somebody who saw it off re- marked -- drew to a close today on a darker, deeply serious note.
The Mobil Oil Corporation increased its profits in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday.

NEWARK, Oct. 23 -- A small but steadily rowing black market in methadone, the synthetic narcotic used as a substitute to treat hard-drug addicts, has emerged in New Jersey, and with rapidly increasing fatal results.

The baseball season finally left the sporting scene yesterday in a parade of antique cars through downtown Oakland, while a crowd of 150,000 lined the curbs and cheered the mustachioed young men driving past.

About 200 veterans, most of whom had fought in long-ago wars and marched to the triumphant acclaim of long-ago crowds, put on their overseas caps, unfurled their flags and paraded before modest crowds on Fifth Avenue yesterday as proudly as if the armistice had just been proclaimed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Henry Kissinger returned to the capital from Saigon tonight amid continuing speculation that a Vietnam or all-Indochina cease-fire was near, but with no firm agreement to end the war apparently reached.
Seven leaders of Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish groups have praised President Nixon for his "noble efforts in inspiring our country toward a greater commitment of moral values."

CAIRO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Negotiators from feuding Yemen and Southern Yemen reached an agreement today that outlines steps toward unifying the two countries, the official Egyptian Middle East News Agency reported.

Florynce Kennedy, a black attorney, Ti-Grace Atkinson, feminist author, and three other women militants were arrested yesterday for refusing to move during a Feminist party "kiss-off" demonstration in front of a Nixon campaign office at 520 Madison Avenue.

All that was necessary for a bettor to capitalize on both ends of the Firenze Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday was to have a liking for Angel Cordero and for No. 5 on the program. The amiable jockey from Puerto Rico won both ends of the split race, making him truly the winner of the Firenze, and each of his mounts was No. 5.
HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 23 -- Dr. Walter Neumann's 43-foot sloop, Sitzmark, out of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was the winner yesterday of the Storm Trysail Club's fourth annual race to Chesapeake Bay.
" America, Hurrah?" is the theme of the National Arts Antiques Festival, which opened last weekend at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Cambodian ministers denied a report today that Cambodia was negotiating with guerrilla leaders in the countryside.

The New York City Charter Revision Commission established by Governor Rockefeller will name a Puerto Rican lawyer in Brooklyn as a temporary paid member today to give representation to both Brooklyn and Puerto Ricans.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23--Senator George McGovern visited patients in the United States Naval Hospital here today to dramatize his Veterans Day pledge to provide jobs, education and health care for veterans of the Vietnam war.
Seven prisoners made a daring and well-planned escape from the Manhattan House of Detention (the Tombs) early yesterday in the first jailbreak from the present building since it was opened in 1941.

The International Telephone Telegraph Corporation said yesterday its French subsidiary, Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, would deliver to the Soviet telegraph administration in 1973 an electronic message-switching system valued at about $1.3-million.

STANFORD, Calif. -- Administration spokesmen have argued that the United States cannot unilaterally withdraw from Vietnam without inviting a vast bloodbath. In support of this thesis, they assert that following the Communist takeover in North Vietnam in 1954 a massacre occurred resulting in the killing of more than 50,000 people and the indirect deaths of hundreds of thousands more.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday. Oct. 24 -- Extensive fighting was reported yesterday in the center of South Vietnam, with Communist forces concentrating their attacks around the city of Pleiku.

PEKING, Oct. 23 (Agence France-Presse) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed head of state of Cambodia, said here today that Le Duc Tho had told him a week ago that "the most difficult and delicate" part of the Vietnam peace talks still remained to be held.

PARIS -- "We ought to die the death that pleases us," wrote Seneca. The remark is quoted by Henry de Montherlant in "LaMaree du Soir" ("The Evening Tide"), published a few months ago. It has turned out to be his last book, for last month Montherlant died the death of his liking, or at least of his choosing: He shot himself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that United States attorneys in Florida had taken seven months to act on the spurious campaign letter accusing him of illicit sexual affairs.

Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia, who is currently seeking a second term, introduced immigration bills while in Congress for six alien physicians who later contributed to his 1968 campaign for Governor.

PARIS, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he expected an Indochina cease-fire to be announced before the end of the month, but that a full peace settlement would come later.
Back in 1931, "Of Thee I Sing" hit the Broadway musical stage, and thousands cheered. Tonight, in a special adaptation, it hits television and millions may wonder what the cheering was all about.

The statement that the difference between incumbent Representative Bella Abzug and her opponent, Priscilla Marbury Ryan, is simply one of style greatly underestimates Mrs. Abzug's achievements and exaggerates Mrs. Ryan's past political role.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Oct. 23 -- Skateland was a delight today for hockey fans and autograph seekers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will hold public hearings next month or early in December to determine whether it will ask Congress to repeal legislation granting mutual funds exemption from price-fixing laws, William J. Casey, chairman of the commission, said here yesterday.
" Even if we win tomorrow," said Sparky Anderson on the eve of the seventh game showdown in the World Series, "my opinion won't change. I'll still think that the best team in baseball is Pittsburgh."

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Some expected high-level ticket-splitting and the margin by which President Nixon loses Essex County will determine the outcome of the election in this northern New Jersey county.

ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 23 (AP) -- President Nixon, in a recorded message for Veterans Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery, said today "Hope is strong for a full generation of peace as American troops return home from a distant conflict."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- Extensive fighting was reported yesterday in the center of South Vietnam, with Communist forces concentrating their attacks around the city of Pleiku.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -Richard J. Sullivan. Alfred E. Johnson. Joseph A. Bosco. Fred B. Burke. John Kramer.

Today, Oct. 24, should be proclaimed "U.N. Day of Shame," and the United States should withdraw from the United Nations, a full-page advertisement sponsored by "ad hoc committees" of the John Birch Society urges in today's editions of The New York Times.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 21 -- Harold Hendren stood in the doorway of the Decca free-load room, shaking hands with assorted disk jockeys and songwriters, pickers and promoters.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 -- The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped to $31.9-million, or 61 cents a share, from the year-earlier $6.2-million, or 12 cents a share. The profit was the highest for a third quarter since 1950.

BIRMINGHAM Ala., Oct. 20 -- The Concentrated Employment Program in this grimy steel town has had to fight hard for its survival. As a result, it has become one of the most activist and successful in the country.

PARAMUS, Oct, 23 -- Like Golden Glovers clamoring for a chance to step into the ring with Muhammad All, close to 100 chess players of widely varying abilities and experience, turned out at the Bergen Mall Shopping Center today for an opportunity to face a few of the world's top-ranked players.

Voters will decide 33 races for the United States Senate on Nov. 7. In a few states the outcome is a foregone conclusion. In others such as Georgia and Louisiana the contests are being fought out solely in terms of personalities.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -Senator George McGovern visited patients in the United States Naval Hospital here today to dramatize his Veterans Day pledge to provide jobs, education and health care for veterans of the Vietnam war.
Bond prices bounded ahead yesterday amid mounting evidence of progress toward an end to the fighting in Indochina.
Increased hopes that progress was being made toward a cease-fire in Indochina sent prices higher yesterday in the over-the-counter market and on the American Stock Exchange.

The mutilated body of a 9-year-old boy was found last night on the roof of a four-story walkup apartment house in Harlem. The police were seeking the killer and investigating a possible link with a similar slaying nearby several months ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The editor of the Republican National Committee newsletter said today that he had sent various Democratic Presidential aspirants information about other contenders during the New Hampshire primary campaign because he had "wanted to do what I could to help" them attack each other.

Robert Huebner, West Germany's newest grandmaster, won the gold medal for the top result in the Olympics in Yugoslavia. The 23 year-old philology student, playing board one for his team, had seven victories and six draws in the finals, narrowly surpassing his leading rivals, Czechoslavakia's Vlastimil Hort and Hungary's Lajos Portisch.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 23 (AP) Turkish hijackers surrendered late today and freed more than 60 hostages whom they had held aboard a Turkish jetliner for 38 hours at the airport at Sofia, Bulgaria.

The Weyerhaeuser Company, the nation's largest maker of timber products and a major producer of pulp and paper, turned in the highest results of any forest-products company in the three and nine months ended Sept. 24, a report yesterday from the company's Tacoma, Wash., headquarters indicated.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 23 -- The designation of Nassau and Suffolk Counties as the Long Island Standard Metropolitan Area had been sought by municipal officials and the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry for many years.

SALT LAKE CITY -- The nation's police continue to regard themselves as a scorned minority in a hostile society, judging by some of the speches at the annual convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police here last week.

NEWARK, Oct. 23--Peter J. Bridge will mark his 20th day in the Essex County Jail tomorrow when Superior Court Judge James R. Giuliano is scheduled to say whether he will dismiss the grand jury to which Mr. Bridge's fortunes are tied.

Chuck Tanner, who charmed the moody Dick Allen into a happy slugger and the lowly Chicago White Sox into pennant contenders in two seasons, was named yesterday the American League manager of the year by the Associated Press.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The North Vietnamese delegation to the Vietnam talks here suggested today that if a peace agreement did not come to fruition soon, it could mean that President Nixon has been mounting an elaborate electoral charade.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday third-quarter operating revenues of $117.9-million against $107.5-million a year ago.
The Hush Puppies apparently fit, so Wolverine World Wide is going to let Wells, Rich, Greene wear 'em.

HARTFORD, Oct. 23 -- The Connecticut Citizen Action Group, an organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, today released profiles of Connecticut's 149 General Assembly members up for re-election. The profiles seek to kindle voters' lagging interest in their local legislature and in the major issues confronting their state senators and representatives.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- There were signs yesterday that Henry A. Kissinger had achieved some success in his five-day effort here toward a settlement of the Vietnam war, but evidently without having reached a conclusive agreement with President Nguyen Van Thieu.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 21 -- Harold Hendren stood in the doorway of the Decca freeload room, shaking hands with assorted disk jockeys and songwriters, pickers and promoters.
The transit policemen's union said yesterday its men would cover the city's subways today "with a blanket of summonses" as part of their rule-book work slowdown against the Transit Authority.

In addition to the memories of entrechats past that they left in Poland, the New York City Ballet, which came home Sunday night, also left behind its favorite piece of gray linoleum. The linoleum had been used to cover the stage floor of the New York State Theater and almost every other stage the City Ballet danced on around the world.

Peter J. Bridge, who was sent to jail for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about a news article that he wrote for the now defunct Evening News of Newark, describes his life in the Essex County Jail in the following article.

Pay television on a regular basis will come to the metropolitan New York area for the first time Friday, when a subscription television service offering professional basketball and hockey games begins operating on Long Island.

NEWARK, Oct. 23 -- Peter J. Bridge will mark his 20th day in the Essex County Jail tomorrow when Superior Court Judge James R. Giuliano is scheduled to say whether he will dismiss the grand jury to which Mr. Bridge's fortunes are tied.
School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has set Nov. 15 as the deadline for all city principals to submit plans for teacher and student safety in their schools.
MIAMI, Oct. 23 -- The spread of the economically harmful screwworm fly in Florida has apparently been contained by prompt wide-scale Federal and state action.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- International trade experts warned today that the world might first have to bring inflation under control if it was to achieve a stable monetary system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, suggested today that all the federally subsidized housing programs be abolished, a step that would do away with most of his department in the process.

Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware, Inc., home furnishings, jewelry and gifts retailer, will more than double its space in Westbury, L. I., to 440,000 square feet, making it the largest store of its kind in the metropolitan area and one of the country's biggest suburban stores.

" Katy-did, she-did" sings out the tireless musician of the insect world. And now, high-speed movies, synchronized millisecond for millisecond with tape recordings of the melodious insect, disclose how the complicated courtship song is sung.
William W. Moore, executive director of the National Council on Alcoholism, has been named executive director of the American Heart Association. The appointment is effective Dec. 1.

David Clayton-Thomas, bestknown in this country as the former lead singer for Blood, Sweat and Tears, made a convincing solo debut at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night. Backed by a solidly swinging rhythm and blues-styled group, he demonstrated a versatility in both style and substance that rarely had been apparent in his work with B. S T.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A tentative contract agreement was reached tonight between The Cleveland Plain Dealer and the striking Cleveland Newspaper Guild.
The New York Giants began preparing yesterday for Sunday's game against the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium, a game that could put them in first place in the Eastern Division.
Twelve art works whose total worth is estimated at more than $500,000 were stolen last Thursday night from the Caramoor Center of Music and the Arts in Katonah, N. Y.

PARIS, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he expected an Indochina cease-fire to be announced before the end of the month, but that a full peace settlement would come later.
The transit policemen's union said yesterday its men would cover the city's subway today "with a blanket of summonses" as part of their rule-book work slowdown against the Transit Authority.
Two of the nation's major copper companies, the Anaconda Company and the Phelps Dodge Corporation, released third-quarter reports yesterday showing turnarounds after losses in 1971.
" I keep saying anybody can win in this league." That was Coach Henry Stram speaking, a ruffled Henry Stram after the victoryless Philadelphia Eagles had upset his Kansas City Chiefs by 21-20.
GAZA, Oct, 23 -- "The thing to remember about Gaza," an Israeli officer in the military government here said today "is that nothing very good or very bad ever lasts very long."
HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 23 -- Dr. Walter Neumann's 43-foot sloop, Sitzmark, out of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was the winner yesterday of the Storm Trysail Club's fourth annual race to Chesapeake Bay.
Senator George S. McGovern had trouble with electronic rings, fadeouts and bleeps on all hour-long telethon last night.
A complaint that the Reader's Digest magazine discriminates against women employes has been dismissed by the State Division of Human Rights.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 23 -- Sargent Shriver, wearing a new silver prisoner-of-war bracelet on Veterans Day, charged the Nixon Administration today with suppressing job opportunities and educational benefits for G.I.'s -- programs he said would have the highest priority in a new McGovern-Shriver G.I. Bill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -Henry Kissinger returned to the capital from Saigon tonight amid continuing speculation that a Vietnam or all-Indochina cease-fire was near, but with no firm agreement to end the war apparently reached. "We made some progress," Mr. Kissinger said, but he refused to elaborate.

3 Inmates Hunted in Jailbreak A search continued for three of five prisoners who broke out of the Camden County Jail annex in Gloucester Township Sunday night. Still at large were Frank J. Huryan, 19 years old, of Lindenwold; George Ennis, 19, of Collingswood, and John W. Humphrey, 18, of Gloucester City. Charles Mraz, 24, and Glenn Frampton, 20, both of Camden, were recaptured early Monday.

Henry Kissinger has come home from Saigon amid thick rumors that a cease-fire in Vietnam is near, to be followed by a political settlement of the war. This has prompted George McGovern to say that he, for one, would "rejoice" if the war could be ended, "no matter the political impact."

The Department of Agriculture hinted over the weekend that China might be in the market for additional United States wheat. China, whose wheat production was hurt by drought earlier this year, has bought some 160 million bushels of wheat in the world market, including about 15 million bushels from the United States in October.

I was quite surprised to see Senator McGovern quoted in the Sept. 26 Times to the effect that "Mr. Nixon has loaded the Federal Power Commission with spokesmen for the big utilities and big oil companies." The article proceeds to quote a memorandum issued by "McGovern aides" stating that "Pinckney (sic) Walker had been a consultant to natural gas companies before becoming a member of the power commission. . . ."

When Tammany Hall was in its heyday a half-century ago, its leaders and Samuel Koenig, then the city's Republican boss, would regularly make deals for the allocation of judgeships and other political patronage. The Democrats always got the lion's share because of their enormous edge in voting strength, but it suited their purpose to keep the G.O.P. as a contented vassal.

VIENNA, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -A nationwide strike of thousands of doctors and dentists has almost paralyzed the Austrian health service and has hurt the civic pride of the average Austrian, at the same time: Austria has one of the lowest strike rates in Western Europe.
ENID, Okla. -- Representative Ed Edmondson smiled and pushed the newspaper clipping across the coffee shop table to an acquaintance.

An amiable and racy musical, "Pippin," which arrived at the Imperial Theater last night, has three great things to commend it. It is one of the best musical stagings to be seen on Broadway in years, it is most beautifully designed and it might well do for the actor Ben Vereen what "Cabaret" did for Joel Grey.

BOHEMIA, L.I., Oct. 23 -- President Nixon, telescoping virtually all of his New York metropolitan area campaigning into a single day's swing through Westchester County and Long Island, sounded familiar campaign themes and called for pluralities greater than those he received in the 1968 election.
While talks and speculation linked to a possible cease-fire in Indochina continued, Wall Street staged another peace rally yesterday. Glamour issues once again scored the best gums.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The man at the door said he was from the famous Spoilsport Poll. We were ecstatic. An American dream had come true.
HARTFORD, Oct. 23 -- Construction work in most of Connecticut was halted today by a laborers' strike.

MADRID, Oct. 23 -- A Government effort to exclude teachers who are considered politically undesirable from the universities and high schools has helped spotlight serious economic problems in the schools and in Spanish society in general.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 23 -Economic activity between Nationalist China and Japan has been continuing without major disruption since the two countries severed diplomatic relations three weeks ago.

When Thomas F. Willers was brought into the company now known as Champion International last February as president, the general impression on Wall Street was that he would be taking over the top post before too long.

TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Oct. 23 -- After declining for several days to talk about the war, Vice President Agnew lashed out today at North Vietnam, accusing its Government of open aggression in Southeast Asia.

President Thieu's grudging prediction that there may soon be a cease-fire in Indochina reinforces speculation that Washington and Hanoi are close to agreement on terms for a cessation of hostilities. But the South Vietnamese leader has made clear that he will do all in his power to block a political settlement, again sharply rejecting any coalition with the Communists and setting conditions for a cease-fire that may not be attainable.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 24 (AP) -Julius Erving scored 35 points and the Virginia Squires broke open the game in the last three minutes to defeat the Memphis Tams, 123-111, tonight in American Basketball Association action.

After signing legislation to increase veterans' educational benefits, President Nixon was greeting the veterans he had invited to the White House when one of them, Larry Kirk, caught the President's eye. Mr. Kirk, a 33-year-old veteran who lost both legs below the knees and part of one arm in combat in Vietnam, told the President he wanted to become a White House fellow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- A contract to clear sunken vessels from the approach channel of Chalna in Bangladesh was signed today by the United Nations and a group of international salvage concerns.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- John Henry Jones, who escaped from a North Carolina prison in 1954 and since then has lived in fear of discovery, is now a free man.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -The National Park service announced today a worldwide search for a small 18th century water-color.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported here yesterday development of a "superconducting" alternating current generator that could provide a new standard of power generation.
To celebrate the 75th anniversary of its London branch, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company gave a luncheon yesterday at Claridge's, the London hotel, for a group of British financiers and businessmen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Sargent Shriver struck angrily today at "turncoat Democrats" and "liars" who he said were conducting a "smear campaign" against his Presidential running mate, Senator George McGovern.

Jackie Robinson, who made history in 1947 by becoming the first black baseball player in the major leagues, suffered a heart attack in his home in Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning and died at Stamford Hospital at 7:10 A.M. He was 53 years old.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 24 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan have exchanged letters in an effort to resolve a deadlock over the Kashmir cease-fire line, informed sources said tonight.
The Washington Redskins will be in the local pro football scene the next three weeks because they play the Giants and Jets here on successive Sundays and then the Giants again in Washington.
The East Mid-Manhattan Chamber of Commerce held a ceremony yesterday to celebrate the planting of eight honey locust trees on a commercialized stretch of 86th Street.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- At 4:10 P.M. on the big wall clock in Room 602 of the New Jersey Superior Court here, Judge James R. Giuliano pronounced the six words that Peter J. Bridge had been waiting nearly three weeks to hear.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Two Brooklyn police detectives were arrested yesterday, accused of having arranged for the dismissal of a criminal case against four persons linked to a Canarsie junkyard trailer that has been named as a covert Mafia meeting place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The White House combined some optimism with a dose of caution today in describing the results so far of Henry A. Kissinger's efforts in Paris and Saigon to achieve a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

Zoe Caldwell and George Grizzard are the latest major replacements in the forthcoming production of Arthur Miller's play, "The Creation of the World and Other Business," whose opening now has been set for Nov. 30 instead of Nov. 20 at the Shubert Theater.
REA Express resumed surface shipments and normal Air Express service yesterday as a majority of striking workers went back to work following a four-day national strike.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- An A-6 Fighter-Bomber crash-landed on the deck of the United States aircraft carrier Midway off Vietnam last night killing four men and injuring 22 others, a spokesman for the Navy said today.

Another round was completed yesterday in the Julius Erring case. A three-judge panel headed by Harold R. Medina, in answer to Erving's appeal of an injunction prohibiting him from playing with any other professional basketball team other than the Virginia Squires, affirmed the Federal District Court's decision to continue the injunction until an arbitrator was named in the contract dispute.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Maury Wills, who stole more bases than any other major league baseball player in history, was placed on waivers today by the Los Angeles Dodgers, who also offered him an instructor's job.

DALLAS, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Police Chief Frank Dyson disclosed last night, that he had temporarily stopped sending the police into black neighborhoods with arrest warrants. Three Negroes have been shot by policemen in the past two weeks, and blacks have protested with demonstrations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Senator Harold E. Hughes said in a statement today that he Air Force decision to dismiss all remaining charges against Maj. Gen. John D. Lavelle was "in effect, a slap on the wrist for flagrant violations of orders."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -The Price Commission has under way an investigation to determine whether major oil companies and independent refiners have made disguised and illegal increases in the wholesale price of gasoline.

Congressional contests in the metropolitan area, including Connecticut and New Jersey, will be discussed in subsequent editorials. While it is not possible to comment here on all the House races elsewhere in the nation, there are members of both parties whose service during the past two years deserves special recognition.

Foreign buyers, two of them from Tokyo, were among the successful bidders for 19th- and 20th-century works of art that included 11 paintings consigned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum pieces, appraised to bring about $314,400, instead raced ahead of presale estimates for virtually each piece to reach a total of $547,500.

Three pediatric radiologists moved X-ray viewing boxes from their hospitals to a hotel here yesterday to demonstrate how chest X-rays can help save the lives of many newborn infants as they sruggle to breathe during the first hours of life.
Unti Bob Tucker caught six passes against St. Louis last Sunday, Giant fans must've thought the tight end had become lost in somebody's intricate zone defense.
Brooklyn District Attorney Gold continues to titillate us with new disclosures from that trailer in the Canarsie junkyard, and the media continue to report it as if it has been factually proved.

A City Council committee demanded yesterday that the Police Department change its regulations to permit policemen to moonlight as security guards in city schools to curb the recent outbreak of robberies of teachers and parents.

Brooklyn's Chelsea Theater -- the best thing the borough has had since the Dodgers left -- has for the first time come down from its attic in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Last night it made its debut, as it were, in one of the academy's regular theaters, giving the premiere of "Lady Day -- A Musical Tragedy."
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks blew a 57-43 half-time lead, then rallied tonight behind Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Mickey Davis, a rookie, to defeat the Buffalo Braves, 109-92.

Thanks to a little bit of luck last Sunday and a lot of running the week before, the New York Jets have put two victories together for the second time this season, have a 4-2 won-lost record and are once again playoff contenders.
A persisting deadlock in negotiations between Indian and Pakistani officials on a future dividing line in Kashmir dims hope for an urgently needed larger peace settlement on the Indian subcontinent.

In a dinner speech to the Conservative party in New York, Vice President Agnew enunciated the overriding issue of the present Presidential campaign, and, in doing so, made the most effective argument for the election of Senator George McGovern, the Democratic candidate.

President Nixon's hard line against legal relief for war objectors -- expressed at the Oct. 16 meeting of the League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia is distressing. It also shows remarkable inconsistency.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- A pair of free throws by Gail Goodrich gave Los Angeles a one-point lead with 43 seconds left tonight and the Lakers, helped by a 33-point performance from Jerry West, stopped Houston the rest of the game to take a 112-107 decision from the Rockets.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 -- About 12 pupils at the Daycroft School, a private Christian Science preparating school here, have been stricken by polio, the State Health Department reported today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Rene Robert and Gerry Meehan each scored second-period goals tonight to give Buffalo a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins and move the Sabres into a tie for first place with Montreal in the National Hockey League's Eastern Division.

Cooks at home who are weary of chaining themselves to the stove for 48 hours before every party in order to emerge, flushed and drained, with a complex bu triumphant meal cannot be blamed for yearning after shortcuts to culinary preeminence in their crowd.

Two of the inmates who escaped from the Manhattan House of Detention for Men (the Tombs) on Monday were recaptured yesterday and a third inmate surrendered at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. Still at large are four others who fled the Tombs by sliding down a rope of bedsheets from the fourth floor.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Glenn W. Turner and two of his Florida businesses have been ordered to show cause Nov. 15 why they have not refunded $182,510 to Washington citizens and why they should not pay a $25,000 civil penalty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -Australis, who won the green and open jumper high point championships of the United States more than five years ago, still hasn't lost her touch.

A favorite media topic these days is the apparent indifference of the public to the accusations of corruption being made against the Nixon Administration. Almost to a man our pundits, commentators and editorial writers are busy analyzing the nature of this tolerance and prophesying dire things for our society as a result of such casual concern for integrity in government.
ATLANTA, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Southern states use voter registration as a means of keeping minority citizens from voting, a report of the Voter Education Project charges.

Two men were killed and three others injured yesterday in a pileup of nine vehicles on the Staten Island Expressway that snarled traffic during the height of the morning rush hour, the police reported.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 -- Senator George McGovern, making his harshest attack on the President, declared tonight that the United States faced a "moral and a constitutional crisis of unprecedented dimensions" because of "widespread abuse of power" by the Nixon Administration.
James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that he opposes further cuts in the level of negotiated rates during the current depressed cycle of the securities industry.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- A young California businessman said today that he had been recruited and paid by Donald H. Segretti to sabotage Democratic political rallies and gather intelligence from the party's campaign headquarters.

Four members of the District 18 Community School Board appealed yesterday to the City Board of Education to overrule Monday night's decision by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner reassigning 32 black children to Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie.

RSR Corporation and St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday they had reached agreement in principle for RSR to acquire all of the capital stock of Quemetco, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of St. Joe.

The hair was longer, and one player even sported a Buffalo Bill goatee, but the Philadelphia Flyers played no differently from last season as they collapsed before the Rangers in a 6-1 drubbing last night. New York won all six meetings last season.

The stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday as investors awaited further developments in the negotiations for a truce in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -A three-year study by a New York University research team has produced dramatic evidence of a major cause of the terror that afflicts public housing residents in many major cities: The higher the building, the higher the crime rate.

The new Circle in the Square Theater, the first new major Broadway house to open in 44 years, will open its doors tonight in a splurge of nostalgia for its own Off-Broadway past and with its sights set on becoming something of an innovation in the history of the Great White Way.

TRENTON, Oct. 25--With virtually everyone around here warning gloomily of municipal financial crises, Governor Cahill could hardly wait to announce today that he had "good news"--a $4.3-million tax windfall for financially pressed local governments.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct 25 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Council cited the University of California at Berkeley today for 21 rules infractions, including a scheme to get junior college credit for two prospective athletes through fraud, and put the school on probation until 1975.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- One hot day in Cairo a young Egyptian saw a Saint Laurent dress in the street. "I'm going to Paris," he announced.

Lowe's Companies, Inc., a North Carolina-based retailer, was the recipient last night of the gold "Oscar-or-Industry" award for the best corporation report in 1971. Presented by Financial World magazine, the business "Oscar" is offered annually to encourage publication of more information and more readable annual statements for shareowners.

More than 100 people -- Japanese-Americans, Chinese-Americans, blacks, Puerto Ricans and whites -- held a demonstration on Broadway outside the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Building yesterday to protest against what they said was the union's racist advertising campaign.

Norman Norell, the dean of American fashion designers, died yesterday at the age of 72 in Lenox Hill Hospital. While the parents and supporters of 32 black children clamored outside barricades manned by the police at John Wilson Junior High School 211, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday, classes resumed with no serious visible problems.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25 -- The Nobel Memorial Prize for economics went today to an American and a Briton whose theories help to assess business disk and government economic and welfare policies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Prices are expected to rise soon for frozen and canned foods as a result of Price Commission approval of increases sought by three companies.

The Standard Oil Company of California and the Pennzoil Company reported yesterday higher earnings for the quarters and nine-month periods, while the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company announced profit declines for both periods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Nixon, in his fifth radio campaign speech, restated today his support for Federal aid to nonpublic schools and his opposition to court-ordered busing and promised to press for legislation to implement both policies.

Lucille Ball has been signed to play the title role in the movie "Auntie Mame," it was confirmed by Warner Bros., producers of the projected adaptation of the Broadway musical "Mame."

But when the City Center Acting Company presented the play yesterday at the Good Shepherd - Faith Church, it was an antic disputation on the meaning of theater and of life.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three and 12 months ended Sept. 30. The report placed revenues at $652.6-million for the September quarter against $569.5-million a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Nixon vetoed today nine bills that he said would "breach the budget" by some $704-million in this fiscal year and $1.9-billion in the next.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Senator George McGovern's charge today that President Nixon was planning a "major assault on American labor" is evidently based, at least in part, on two memorandums written for the Employment Standards Administration of the Department of Labor.
Tornadoes touched down in Georgia, Florida and Alabama yesterday, causing widespread property damage but only one report of minor injuries.
PATERSON, Oct. 27 -- One of the things Thomas C. Rooney Jr., the Democratic candidate for Mayor, and Edwin J. Englehardt, his Republican opponent, agree on is that each is the man to beat.

The career of the American painter Edwin Dickinson has been a long and distinguished one, and yet his art is without a fixed, secure position in either our minds or our museums. His painting seems to belong to the past -- the dead past, as we say -- until we place it alongside what is really dead in that past, and then it reveals a strikingly personal sensitivity and even boldness.
CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Monday, Nov. 13, was set today for the beginning of a new trial in the securities violation case of a self-proclaimed millionaire, Glenn W. Turner.

BORDEAUX, France -- They finished picking at Chateau Lafite on Tuesday at Mouton and Latour on Wednesday. The only activity in the vineyards of the Medoc now is the distant pop of shotguns as the peasants (and some of the proprietors) hunt quail in the early morning mist.

This is the year of healthy exposure of the shortcomings of the judiciary and the administration of justice. Fortunately the highest court of the State of New York -- the Court of Appeals -- has a long and great tradition of legal distinction. Benjamin Cardozo, Samuel Seabury, Irving Lehman and other respected jurists including the present chief judge, Stanley Fuld, have graced this court in Albany. It must remain a sanctuary of law.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 27 -- A victory and a tie in four games hardly means success for most football teams, but it's enough to dispell temporarily those gloomy predictions for Princeton this fall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A person presenting a credit card may some day be able to prove his identity through a computer's memory of his voice. Scientists at Bell Tele phone Laboratories were granted a patent this week for a system of automatic speaker verification.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 27 -- An 11-man military Government was named today to lead the West African nation of Dahomey, less than 24 hours after a coup d'etat in the capital city of Cotonou.

While their players spent another quiet day working themselves into the small frenzy that must be detonated in any important football game, Coach Alex Webster and his staff looked ahead to Sunday's game with the Washington Redskins and sharpened their theories.
CLERMONT - FERRAND, France, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- About 20 survivors were found early today in the wreckage of a French airliner carrying 68 people that crashed last night into a mountain near here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The geologist-astronaut who will go to the moon on Apollo 17 said today there was "a good chance" that the mission would uncover both some of the youngest and some of the oldest lunar rocks ever examined by man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- L. Patrick Gray 3d, the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today that for 22 years the bureau had been compiling "biographical data" on major Congressional candidates. He said he was ending the practice immediately.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Lee Trevino, who was at 142, said he almost quit the tournament because of slow play of other pros and urged officials to penalize the culprits.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct, 27 -- A record total of 1.2-million Puerto Ricans are expected to vote on Nov. 7 in what is shaping up as one of the most hotly contested gubernatorial and legislative elections in the island's history.

DENVER -- Advocates of a partial and unilateral withdrawal of American forces from Europe advance the argument that the Soviet Union has become a status quo power and will not commit an act of aggression against West Europe. On the surface, the argument appears plausible.

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- Warning that Newark faced another "very difficult financial position," Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said here today that the city's property tax rate would have to be raised by as much as 20 per cent next year to make up a projected $37.5-million deficit in the proposed $212-million city budget.
Jackie Robinson received a hero's burial here yesterday, mourned as a man of courage by those who knew him and solemnly saluted as a legend by strangers who never saw him play.

A Federal judge in Trenton said that the trial of D. Louis Tonti, the former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, on extortion charges would begin early next year.

PARIS -- Now that the cold war is easing, and taking more ambiguous forms, and Europe is picking herself up, the United States, which has imprudently dispersed its forces in an ambitious world policy, strongly feels the need to limit its efforts: domestic inflation, and the balance of payments deficit impose a reduction in military expenses in the domain of nuclear strategy as in that of foreign engagements.

The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $743-million for the first nine months. This compared with $615-million a year earlier. Hard frost comes and on a still, star-shot night the countryman wakens at two in the morning and listens and wonders what happened. He lies there, tense, until he hears the rustling of crisp leaves, the far-off hooting of a barred owl.

MANILA, Oct. 23 -- In the waning days of his second and constitutionally last term as president of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos has conferred on himself absolute power.

In the seven years since her New York piano debut, Mary Richter Snyder has apparently built an active performing career in the Middle West, with radio and television appearances in her home state of Ohio, and various other regional appearances in solo and chamber repertoire.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 29 -- After more than five months of pain and self-doubt, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is beginning to emerge from the shock of an assassin's bullets that had crippled his ambitions as well as his body.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -Dwight L. Chapin, a deputy assistant to President Nixon has acknowledged to Federal investigators that he hired Donald H. Segretti, a young lawyer who is reported to have been a Republican sabotage agent, according to Time magazine.
PARIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A new survey on sex life in France, described as a Gallic Kinsey report, damages the reputation of Frenchmen as expert lovers.
In the first National Football League meeting between the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Rams, the Raiders -- literally -- got off to a fast start on their neighbors from southern California.

Evander and Clinton won yesterday and set up a meeting next Saturday that will decide the football championship of the Manhattan-Bronx Public Schools Athletic League. The winner of that game, which will be played at Evander in the Bronx, will qualify for the semifinal round of the city playoffs.

Palestinian guerrillas hijacked a West German jetliner yesterday over Turkey and won the release of three Arab commandos accused of taking part in the slaying of 11 Israelis at the Olympic Games in Munich on Sept. 5.

TOMS RIVER, Oct. 29 -- The proposed twin off-shore nuclear generating plants, which would be moored within a huge man-made breakwater southeast of Little Egg Inlet, have attracted their first formal government opposition.

Although Emerson Boozer gained 91 yards on 19 carries and scored three touchdowns in the New York Jets' 34-10 victory over the New England Patriots yesterday, all of the game balls went to the Jets' defensive line.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- The pressures on Japan for another revaluation of the yen have become so strong that the question asked in Tokyo today is not whether it will happen, but when, how much, and under what circumstances.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29 -Kuwait has begun diplomatic approaches to Egypt and Jordan in an effort to heal the breach between them before the meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Kuwait next month, according to Arab diplomatic sources.

Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the City School Chancellor, has vowed as his "first responsibility" in the Canarsie dispute to keep open Junior High School 211, where embittered parents have been demonstrating against the admission of 32 black and Puerto Rican youngsters from outside the district.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Pope Paul VI today beatified the late Rev. Michele Rua, the successor of St. John Bosco, who founded the Salesian order in the 19th century. A "blessed" or "beautified" person is a candidate for sainthood.

Whitney reported among other things that "increasingly, President Lon Nol is governing through a smaller and smaller circle of intimates." In addition, the correspondent alleged the lack of government presence in the countryside.

Dancers who have come out of the Alwin NikolaisMurray Louis school or Mr. Nikolais's company tend naturally to conserve their teachers' movement style when they turn to choreography, but they often have their own ideas about where to go next.
The nation's machine tool industry chalked up a 1972 high for new orders in September, according to statistics released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Pope Paul VI today expressed hope that the expected cease-fire in Indochina would represent a "true peace" that would satisfy the present "eagerness for peace that pervades the world."
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Coco Chanel made a name for herself out of a man's polo sweater that she tossed over her shoulders during the chilly season in Deauville.

The State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist upheld yesterday the city Board of Education's decision to assign 32 black and Puerto Rican pupils from Brownsville to predominantly white John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

Four hijackers armed with pistols and a shotgun killed an Eastern Airlines gate agent and wounded another employe at Houston Intercontinental Airport early yesterday before diverting a jet and its 29 passengers to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -Miss Marjorie Simons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Simons of Louisville, Ky., was married here this afternoon to Alexander Philip Federbush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max W. Federbush of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 -- Mounting statewide controversy has persuaded a welfare advisory panel set up by Gov. Ronald Reagan to revise a drastic plan that it had proposed for dealing with California's growing number of illegitimate children.

The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for inter-American journalism will be awarded tomorrow at Columbia University to Tom Streithorst, former Latin-American correspondent for N.B.C. News, Dr. Arturo Uslar Pietri, editor in chief of the Caracas Venezuela, newspaper El Nacional, and Dr. Pedro G. Beltran, former editor and publisher of the newspaper La Prensa, of Lima, Peru.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Japan and China signed a private trade agreement in Peking today calling for $120-million in two-way trade for 1973, up 30 per cent from the expected trade volume for this year.

CARTERET, N. J., Oct. 29 -One can hardly round a corner of this industrial town 10 miles southwest of Manhattan without seeing a tank farm of petroleum or chemical products. Consequently, it was no surprise to find many of the residents of this working-class community on the Arthur Kill, just west of Staten Island, expressing some apprehension for their safety shortly after the series of explosions and fires last week.

DUBLIN, Oct. 29 -- As Sinn Fein, the political arm of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, met here in a conference this weekend, terrorists set off bombs in four hotels and one more in a railroad station.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -President Nixon, in the latest of his series of nationwide radio campaign speeches, denounced his opponent's defense policies today and came out strongly against any possibility of "amnesty for draft dodgers and deserters."

A remarkably vicious assault by Curt Bennett, one of two Ivy Leaguers in the National Hockey League, against the Chicago Black Hawks' Cliff Koroll punctuated last night's commanding 7-1 Ranger victory at Madison Square Garden.
PARIS -- To celebrate England's entry into the European Economic Community, she and France are lending each other two major treasures from their grandest museums.

Scribner, Chancellor of the New York City schools; Jack Zimmer, president of the District 18 community school board; and the Rev. Wilbert B. Miller and Mrs. Joan Boatright, leaders of the parents of the black and Puerto Rican children involved in the dispute.

Seventeenth District: In spite of occasional votes of an overly cautious and conservative sort, we endorse the candidacy of Representative John M. Murphy (Dem.). He should be re-elected basically because of his accomplishments, but also because his opponent, Mario D. Balardino (Rep.-Cons.) is a flamboyantly poor candidate.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba( Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Winnipeg Jets rallied for four consecutivee goals in the third period tonight to defeat the Houston Aeros, 5-3, in a World Hockey Association game. The triumph, Winnipeg's fourth in a row, moved the Jets into first place in the Western Division.

The latest thing in match-making is matching dogs to foster homes. "No crowding, no cages, no lonesome hours while you're away," the brochure for Board-a-Pet Placement Service, Inc., says. The matching is done scientifically, the brochure also says, and it can be done for cats and birds as well as dogs.

A 47-year-old Brooklyn man whom the police described as a small-time hoodlum was shot and killed yesterday morning two blocks west of Police Headquarters in an apparent "hit" by an unknown gunman, the police reported.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Gunmen firing from a passing automobile killed one Belfast youth and wounded another today, police officials said.

RENSSELAERVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Three experts in public -opinion polling -- two of them pollsters -- agreed, at a conference here this weekend, that political polls did not have a "bandwagon effect."
PROVIDENCE, R.I. Oct. 29 -"There are two fine men running for the Senate in Rhode Island," begins a campaign radio spot urging the re-election of Senator Claiborne Pell.
State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger has called for state penalties against the city because he said it was failing to recover tax refunds from welfare recipients.
Bond prices edged lower on a broad front yesterday, apparently reflecting a general letdown now that an end to the Vietnam fighting appears at hand.

Battered by criticism over the way it had administered the primary election here last June, the City Board of Elections is taking unusual steps to make sure that citizens will be able to vote without disruption on Election Day.

The Rockwell Manufacturing Company announced after the close of the stock market yesterday that it had received an offer from the North American Rockwell Corporation to merge Rockwell Manufacturing into North American Rockwell.
Muriel F. Siebert, who in 16 years rose from a $65-a-week research trainee to become the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange, is selling her seat and buying another.

Traffic Cop, well regarded as a sprinter, demonstrated his ability by taking the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old, owned by Mrs. Adele Rand, beat eight rivals in a seven-furlong sprint, and did so with relative ease.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- These are ordinarily the days of growing silence on the nation's wheat farms. The grain sown last spring has been harvested and the winter wheat is planted.

MIAMI, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A criminal court judge refused today to dismiss state notary fraud charges against Bernard L. Barker, one of the five persons accused of political spying on Democratic party national headquarters in the Watergate complex in Washington last June.
TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- The official North Korean press agency said today that the draft of a new North Korean constitution had been completed to prepare for the reunification of the divided peninsula.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The advisory council of the Roman Catholic Church's Synod of Bishops has recommended to the Pope that the synod meet every three years, rather than every two years, as it has been doing. President Nixon has been found in a survey to be receiving twice as much support of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut Catholics and Jews as he did in the 1968 election returns.

New Yorkers no longer need to cross the Atlantic to purchase Fortnum Mason delicacies. Products of the 265-year-old London store, which fed Wellington's officers during the Napoleonic Wars and sent 250 pounds of beef tea to the Crimea for Florence Nightingale are now available at B. Altman Co.

A group of season-ticket holders in various sports, led by the president of the New York Giants fan club, has called on Governor Rockefeller to stop the Yankee Stadium project approved by the city. The group also advocates the creation of a bi-state "sports authority" to be appointed by the governors of New York and New Jersey.

The second annual convention of the Society of American Vintage-Radio Enthusiasts (SAVE) was held last weekend at a Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge in Connecticut. Following several fervent pleas for a revival of radio drama, members attended a Golden Radio Awards Dinner to honor Raymond Edward Johnson, who on "Inner Sanctum" was both the host and the weekly opener of the squeaking door.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A joint task force of Government and securities industry officials was created today to monitor more closely the activities of brokers who specialize in making markets in low-priced, speculative securities.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- With peace in Vietnam seemingly within grasp, there is an element of anachronism in Moscow's latest stage hit, "Under the Skin of the Statue of Liberty," which portrays United States war protesters pitted against helmeted police. Full houses are viewing it at the avant-garde Taganka Theater.

IRVING, Tex., Oct. 30 (AP) -The Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, struggling to stay alive in the race to the 1972 National Football League playoffs, rode the passing arm of their quarterback, Craig Morton, to a 28-24 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

The meeting of the board of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center to discuss the resignation of Jules Irving, artistic director of the Repertory Theater, was postponed yesterday to later this week. The day has not been determined.

MANILA, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- The police said today that a band of about 500 men attacked a 15-man national police detachment in troubled Cotabato Province on Oct. 29 but were repelled after a four-hour fight with Government troops aided by a helicopter gunship.

WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- The United States opened a trade information office yesterday in Warsaw, the first such facility in a Communist country. It will serve as a "home away from home" for American businessmen as well as filling a variety of Polish needs.

NEWARK, Nov. 5 -- Sargent Shriver, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, appeared in this rainy city today in a final effort to deny President Nixon the landslide victory in New Jersey that political leaders from both parties were predicting for him on Tuesday.

Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn returned to something approaching normal yesterday after a 12-day boycott, and most of the 1,003 students in attendance seemed glad to be back and eager to catch up on the work they had missed.

LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today the cities lining up to stage the 1976 Winter Games might have to wait at least four months for a decision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Nixon, promising the American people the rigors of self-reliance instead of the soft life, says he hopes to use the second term to lead the nation out of a crisis of the spirit.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The United Nations today began what promises to be a difficult and politically sensitive task: taking substantive action against international terrorism.

The aftermath of Wednesday's destructive northeaster continued to snarl traffic during the morning and evening rush hours yesterday as isolated flooded areas and hundreds of abandoned cars blocked highways.
Waiters, waitresses and bus boys at 11 well-known Manhattan restaurants went on Strike yesterday for higher pay and other contract improvements.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, has issued a statement expressing disappointment with a Federal report on the state's mental health retardation program.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Youth Board Research Institute, a major operating arm of the scandal-ridden Youth Services Agency, would be dissolved and its activities absorbed in a thorough reorganization of the agency.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Religious beliefs about the origin of man have no place in the science and instruction offered in California's public elementary schools, a state commission told the California Board of Education today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Nixon has sent a personal letter to the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, urging him to accept a cease-fire plan as soon as possible, well-placed Administration officials said today.

The Halston mystique continues. Fashion's man of the hour doesn't try to do anything drastic for spring. He doesn't have to. Practically everything he touches moves into the spotlight -- witness his Ultra (translation: fake) suede coats and dresses, his wrap-skirted suits, his button-front dresses and his caftans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- State and local governments are about to begin receiving billions of dollars of Federal revenue-sharing funds at a time when their fiscal situation is the easiest in many years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The state Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, signaled his candidacy for the national chairmanship yesterday by calling for "changes in personnel and programs" of the party.

BOUND BROOK, Nov. 9 -- Whenever a heavy rain falls, memories are revived here of August, 1971, when tropical storm Doria dropped 11 inches of rain on this town. Floods, resulting from the overflow of the Raritan River and three other streams, did damage totaling millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON -- To carry 49 of the fifty states by heavy popular majorities while your party was being rejected as a claimant for the legislative majority required to execute your programs -- this marks a turbulence among the American people which would lead to at least two more years of bitter national disunity.
Earnings of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, the largest corporate enterprise outside the United States, fell sharply in the quarter and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30.
In a swirl of blue skirt and pixie-cut blonde hair, Janet Lynn spun through the air in a double Axel that brought murmurs of approval from viewers at the Skating Club of New York.

In the aftermath of one of the most complete Republican Presidential sweeps of New York State in memory, the Democratic party nonetheless remains alive and relatively healthy. The Nixon landslide had remarkably little impact on state and local political contests. While there was a gain for Republicans here and there in the State Legislature, these gains were indeed minimal and far below most forecasts.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Britain has decided on humanitarian grounds to exempt individual Rhodesians from some of the economic penalties being carried out against the breakaway colony.

The Redskins are favored over the Giants on Sunday as they attempt to make a sweep -- three straight victories over New York teams. This game will be telecast from Washington, Channel 2 at 1 P.M.

WASHINGTON -- For the American premiere of E. A. Whitehead's "The Foursome," the stage at the Arena Stage is completely filled with clean white crystalline sand. Taylor -- presumably in collaboration with the director, Alan Schneider.

A public offering of one million shares of Arizona Public Service Company common at $23.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by First Boston, Blyth Eastman Dillon and Dean Witter. Horner, White House correspondent of The Washington Star-News. The President did not want the interview published in question-and-answer form, but he did authorize direct quotation. YPRES, Belgium, Nov. 9 -- Softly at first, then solemn and clear, the notes of the Last Post, played on a silver bugle, drift out each night at 8 o'clock over the still Flemish fields near the town of Ypres. The fields contain 130,000 graves -- 40,000 marked, the rest unknown -- of Allied soldiers who died there between 1914 and 1918.

Alexander Slobodyanik played his Philharmonic Hall recital yesterday afternoon under disturbing circumstances, but his performance gave one no reason to doubt his standing, immediately established at his first recital here four years ago. He is one of the more gifted pianists of his generation.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- Juan D. Peron, the populist leader whose 10 years in power left a deep mark on Argentina, is scheduled to return this week after 17 years in exile. There is a strange blend of apathy, fear, excitement and doubt in the country awaiting him.
ROME, Nov. 12 -- While post office departments throughout the world are urging the public to send Christmas mail early, Italians are being warned not to mail any holiday greetings at all.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The New York Giants yielded two touchdowns to Larry Brown in the last 63 seconds of play today and lost to the Washington Redskins, 27-13.

MONTAUK, L.I., Nov. 12 -- For nearly five years Hilda Lindley led the fight for a 900-acre county park over-looking Block Island Sound here. Assistant Secretary of Education Sidney P. Even Mr. Marland's assurance that expenditures in this vital area will not necessarily be reduced below the present austerity level is ominous.
