WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A prominent private research group supported today President Nixon's contention that a tax increase could be avoided in the next few years, but it suggested that Government spending could safely go a little higher than the President seems to want.
Not too long ago, an irate investor in upstate New York decided to seek redress in Delaware against a corporation of that state
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 13 -- British soldiers killed the driver of a stolen car and wounded a bank robber in Belfast today.

Backlash, maintenance of status quo and mistrust of what is perceived as "counterculture" contributed heavily to President Nixon's lopsided majority -- but not to a Republican sweep -- because Senator McGovern, and not the Democrats, was the focal point of the voters' fear. In its preoccupation with domestic concerns the electorate was indifferent, at best, to the agony of millions of fellow human beings in Indochina, daily slaughtered and savaged by our air power.

JAWAND, Afghanistan, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Hundreds of camels are carrying emergency wheat to a score of Afghanistan's remote valleys, promising life to about 160,000 peasants facing starvation for the scond time in a year.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the- counter market declined yesterday in slower trading.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, called on the United States tonight to remove "the obstacles created by the American side literally on the eve of signing" of a Vietnamese cease-fire agreement.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 14 -- The United States command reported yesterday that American planes bombed North Vietnam heavily in a continued effort to block the rush of supplies to Communist forces in South Vietnam.

The invitation to the Dance Theatre of Harlem's gala benefit at the newly refurbished Loew's Victoria Theater on West 125th Street said, "Come on back in ermine, pearls and jeans," and that's what rich and elegant blacks and whites by the hundreds did last night.

A proposal to establish a national court of appeals to ease the workload of the Supreme Court evoked skepticism last night from Chief Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Henry Kearns, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, predicted today that the American balance of trade, which has been running a substantial deficit, would shift into surplus by February or March of next year.
Olin Brass announced yesterday that it planned to increase the price of copper and copper alloy sheet and strip products by 2 cents a pound, effective with shipments of Dec. 4.

Unless the undefeated Miami Dolphins lose four of their next five games and the Jets go undefeated the rest of the season (prospects that seem very unlikely at this point), New York's chances of making the playoffs hinge on getting the elusive "wild card" spot.
Errol Mann, the Detroit kicker, came on the field with five seconds left to play and his assignment was simple. Kick a 33-yard field goal that would give the Lions a 17-16 victory over the Vikings.

Cuban authorities at Jose Marti Airport in Havana said the three gunmen who hijacked a Southern Airways jet there over the weekend would spend the rest of their lives in "four-by-four-by-four-foot" boxes, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, John H. Shaffer, said yesterday.
Five plainclothes patrolmen in the Organized Crime Control Bureau were arrested yesterday on charges of having shielded mob-run gambling on Staten Island.
TOKYO, Nov. 13 -- Premier Kakuei Tanaka dissolved the lower and more powerful house of Parliament today and called a general election for Dec. 10.

A voice speaks the words of Lucretia Mott, the Quaker and Abolitionist who could support 10 demands of the first Convention on Women's Rights, in Seneca Falls, N. Y., in 1848, but wasn't ready for the 11th: the right to vote.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two economists told Congress today that the wage-price controls program should be continued and should be made tougher on prices.

The New York City Board of Education has decided to equip each junior high and high school student with identification cards carrying their photographs, probably beginning next month, in an effort to cut down on school crime.
The New Jersey Supreme Court, reversing a decision that it had made five years ago, yesterday ordered two defendants in a criminal case to submit to voiceprint tests as a means of identification.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Mike Phipps threw a 38-yard touchdown pass to Frank Pitts with 41 seconds left and the Cleveland Browns defeated the San Diego Chargers, 21-17, tonight in a National Football League game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- China's Deputy Foreign Minister today assailed a Soviet proposal for the abolition of force in international relations in some of the strongest language heard in the General Assembly this year.
Five plainclothes patrolmen in the Organized Crime Control Bureau were arrested yesterday on charges of having shielded mob-run gambling on Staten Island.

Clarence Campbell couldn't talk about Bobby Hull yesterday, but virtually everyone else in hockey who was suing or being sued did. Hull, the millionaire, finally did what he had done more often than anyone else playing the game -- score some goals. His pair came on Sun day night in Winnipeg as his Jets scored a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Sharks in a World Association contest.

A Federal study has asserted that New York City has failed to use an opportunity to ease "excessive" civil service requirements under the Emergency Employment Act program that has given Federal funds for city jobs for the unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, will hold top-level policy talks here tomorrow in which he is expected to press for new weapons and seek assurances of continued deliveries of jet fighters, well-placed Administration officials said today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 -- William T. Farr, facing an indefinite jail term for contempt of court, said today he had no intention of disclosing his sources for a 1970 news article, although that would guarantee his freedom.

If men and women run around next summer in Roman striped sweaters, shirts and jackets, in colors brighter than the rainbow, thank Valentino. The Roman couturier, known for the elegance of his designs, brought his spring and summer ready-to-wear collection to New York last week for eventual dispersal to American stores.
Those who delight in calling McGovern "the Goldwater of the left" have missed a most important distinction between these two victims of a ballot avalanche.

Cuban authorities at Jose Marti Airport in Havana said the three gunmen who hijacked a Southern Airways jet there over the weekend would spend the rest of their lives in "four-by-four-by-four-foot" boxes, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, John H. Shaffer, said yesterday.

The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs yesterday announced the arrest of seven men from the metropolitan area, including a City College teacher and a psychologist, in connection with the seizure of 1,100 pounds of hashish.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Nov. 13 -- Senator George McGovern says he is determined to "keep the heat on" President Nixon to end the Vietnam war, to reduce military spending and to reorder national priorities.

Soybeans and soybean meal futures contracts set new life-of-contract highs in most deliveries yesterday in active trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean oil futures also showed some sharp gains.

STOCKTON, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Two former followers of Charles Manson, the hippie cult leader, were among five persons charged today with the slaying of a woman whose body was dug up here four days after her husband's body was unearthed 100 miles away.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 13 -- A record budget for 1973 of $475,144,000, which calls for a decrease in the property-tax rate, was proposed today by Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

PITTSBURGH -- There come times when the cost of seeking to attain an objective promises to exceed by far any value which could accrue from its attainment. At that point wisdom dictates abandonment of pursuit of that objective, whether it be a government's political, or an individual's personal, objective.
A prominent criminal lawyer who was mugged and robbed here in September called yesterday for the formation of a civilian anticrime corps.

Fred J. Borch, who is retiring as chief executive of the General Electric Company, charged here yesterday that the United States had subordinated foreign economic policy and, in effect, now has no foreign economic policy.

A 19-year-old Brooklyn youth was captured early yesterday in a subway station in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section and charged with robbing at gunpoint the drivers of a bus and a cab within five minutes.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Nov. 14 -- Le Duc Tho, the North Vietnamese Politburo member who is in charge of private negotiations with the United States, left Hanoi for Paris today to take part in another round of peace talks, the Hanoi radio reported.

Steel production last week reversed itself after two consecutive weeks of declines and posted a 1.4 per cent gain over the preceding week, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Actual output totaled 2,663,000 net tons for an index of 109.2. This compared with 2,626.000 and an index of 107.6 a week earlier.

A long-term British study of more than 17,000 births has shown that babies weighing less at birth than they should are more likely to suffer from a variety of educational and behavioral deficits by the time they reach school age.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- "American patients hate their doctors. British doctors hate their patients."
Local 1 of the Dining Room Employes Union reported yesterday that it had negotiated new agreements with 14 restaurants but had exended its strike to seven more establishments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church approved today their first pastoral message in four years -- a wide-ranging document on parochial education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Five Democratic Governors joined today the move to replace Jean Westwood at the head of the Democratic National Committee and to give their party what they called "a new sense of direction" after Senator George McGovern's crushing defeat least week.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, called on the United States tonight to remove "the obstacles created by the American side literally on the eve of signing" of a Vietnamese cease-fire agreement.
Interest rates on corporate and tax-exempt bonds moved in sharply opposite directions yesterday while other rates remained steady on light activity.

NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- The foundation of Kawaida Towers stands like a raw wound in the orderly working-class pattern of the North Ward, the current focus of discontent in what has been called the most racially polarized city in America.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 13 -- Communist forces fired 51 large rockets into the airport of the royal Laotian capital of Luang Prabang today, damaging at least five military planes.

Thirty-four food establishments said to have violated the city's Health Code, are on the latest list made public yesterday by the Health Services Administration. Seven places previously cited for violations have corrected them and two others have been ordered closed by the health authorities.

How many more airline passengers must fly with terror, how many airline employes face death or serious injury before the United States Government, the international community and the airlines put safety before politics or profit and take decisive action to curb aerial hijackers?
BRIDGEPORT, Conn. -- It is Tuesday evening, and the weekly meeting of the Social Club in this community of 154,000 residents is in full swing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- In its first policy statement on energy, the American Petroleum Institute said today at its annual meeting that environmentalists would have to compromise on issues if difficulties on energy were to be avoided.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- The controversial renomination of Dr. Carl L. Marburger as New Jersey's State Commissioner of Education was released today by the Senate Judiciary Committee, where he had been blocked by the state's teacher lobby and conservative opponents of school busing.

Sooner or later an airline hijacking is going to result in a real disaster -- hundreds dead in a crash, or a bloody shootout in the sky, or even the reality of something as bizarre as last weekend's threat to crash a hijacked Southern Airways' plane into the Oak Ridge atomic installation.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The British Government, worried about the influx of letter bombs sent to Jews in London and Glasgow, issued a warning today to any government giving "aid or comfort" to terrorists.

There is nothing quite so gloomy as a gloomy comedy -- it is like a skeleton in the soup, or a fly at a feast. It is unnatural, unhappy and undesirable. It is difficult to believe that Melina Mercouri, tawny-haired, brandy-voiced, could be associated with anything undesirable.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam said today that the visit of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. had brought the United States and South Vietnam "closer together'' on a draft peace settlement. Mr. Lam added that there were still some problems requiring "clarification" before Saigon would accept the accord.

The transformation from street gang warfare "on the wrong side of the fence" to gang-busting as an undercover detective with the Brooklyn District Attorney's rackets bureau was accomplished by Douglas Alexander Le Vien Jr., under the kneading of hard-boiled Marine drill instructors at Camp Lejeune, N. C.
A recent issue of the Sport Fishing Institute's news bulletin reveals that in 1970 sport fishermen spent nearly $5-billion (including expenditures for goods and services directly related to angling).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for the resumption of the Pentagon papers trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr., who are accused of making public the top-secret study of the origins of the Vietnam war.

HOLLYWOOD -- When Paul Morrissey's film "Heat" previewed here recently, he arrived in an antique car, smiled through the beam of a welcoming spotlight and marched past a platoon of Hollywood columnists extending microphones.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13 -- The Lebanese Army, acting on orders from the Government, took over the maintenance of law and order today to cope with strikes and demonstrations in protest against the killing of two persons in a clashon Saturday
The Justice Department filed yesterday an antitrust suit to nullify the acquisition of the Great Western Foods Company of Knoxville, Tenn., by the Federal Company of Memphis.

To the Editor: The pollsters predicted a landslide victory for President Nixon and the people made it so. Thus, the vast majority of voting Americans demonstrated their appreciation for the political acumen that Richard Nixon afforded the nation in his first term as President.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the Union Carbide Corporation and the Bechtel Corporation said yesterday that they were looking into the feasibility of building and operating a uranium enrichment facility that would cost in excess of $1.5-billion.
MANILA, Nov. 13 -- The Philippine Government took steps today to try in absentia accused Filipino Communist rebels who have gone underground.
MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, said tonight that the United States Presidential election had strengthened the prospects of world peace.

HARTFORD, Nov. 13 -- They stood face-to-face, weapons poised at three paces, the president of the University of Hartford and the chairman of the student association, both in shiny top hats and braced for the duel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A Federal judge today postponed the trial of former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois, who is charged with conspiracy and bribery, until Jan. 3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Supreme Court rejected today a petition for review filed by William T. Farr, a former reporter for The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, who was cited for contempt for refusing to tell the trial judge in the Charles Manson murder case who had given him a copy of a statement by a witness about the Manson "family's" murderous schemes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Washington this afternoon and immediately flew by helicopter to Camp David. There he reported to President Nixon on his special mission to Saigon to persuade President Nguyen Van Thieu to join with the United States and North Vietnam in reaching an Indochina settlement.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 13 -- Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, charged here today that "overly ambitious administrative grabs by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board" were making controversial issues in the savings and loan industry "more volatile."

NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman declared today a seven-day "cooling-off period" in the racial controversy surrounding the construction of a black-sponsored high-rise project in this city's predominantly white North Ward.

KENT, Conn., Nov. 13 -- At the top of his forms as he scrapes the bottom of the human psyche, William Steig, the cartoonist, tomorrow shrugs off his 65th birthday and the stimulating despair of a lifetime.

At an emotion-charged meeting that was marked by frequent outbursts from the audience, the community school board for Brooklyn's District 18 paved the way last night for a new legal challenge to the Board of Education's action last month assigning 32 black and Puerto Rican children from Brownsville to John Wilson Junior High School 211 in Canarsie.

It was 4 P.M., and the blue-clad police officers lined up for inspection in the glittering new 77th Precinct house in Brooklyn. Most of them were big and burly -with two notable exceptions -- and they all carried the paraphernalia of the cop on the beat: A .38-caliber Smith Wesson police special, handcuffs, blackjack, night stick, whistle.

The re-elected President Nixon says he will not exempt the Defense Department from his cuts in Government spending. So much to the good. But his interview with The Washington Star-News revealed a strange quirk in his thinking, one that at the very least is open to dangerous misinterpretation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration says that "not a single strand" of lead Christmas tree tinsel should be found on store shelves this Yule season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson promised today that the energy strategies and programs that President Nixon would present to the nation "in the coming year will be fully equal to his initiatives to the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China."

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 14 -Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that local and state resources were not equal to the task of saving the cities and called on the Federal Government to assume the burden of their salvation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -The Senate's basic legislative course in the coming two years may well be set, long before the new Congress settles down to business, by a decision on the composition of the Finance Committee.
The pollsters who predicted the outcome of the recent Presidential election ought to try their hand at picking the outcome of the Ivy League football race. Even the computers are frantic.

The long - awaited decisive penetration of the 1,000 level by the Dow-Jones industrial average was greeted in Wall Street yesterday as an event of mainly psychological significance for the stock market.

When Sir Noel Coward was once accused of writing thin plays, he instantly resolved to write nothing but fat plays in the future. It is a resolve that Paul Zindel, whose new play, "The Secret Affairs of Mildred Wild," opened last night at the Ambassador Theater, should take instantly to heart. It seems perilously thin.

Whenever it rains, most other New Yorkers merely get wet, but the 12 tenants of a converted town house across from the Metropolitan Museum of Art say they get soaked because their building's roof tends to leak at the slightest provocation.

LUFKIN, Tex., Nov. 14 -Former Representative Martin Dies, first chairman of the controversial House Committee on Un-American Activities, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old. engaging in "un-American activities."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Danny Grant, Murray Oliver and J. P. Parise scored in a three-minute span of the first period tonight and kept the Minnesota North Stars unbeaten against the Los Angeles Kings over the last four National Hockey League seasons with a 4-1 victory.

SAVANNAH, GA. Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The helmsman at the wheel when the freighter African Neptune rammed the Sidney Lanier Bridge last Tuesday, killing 10 motorists, insisted today that he had been given incorrect steering commands.

In what was believed to be the largest common stock sale ever made by an electric utility, the Southern Company yesterday afternoon raised $172million by selling 8.3 million shares at competitive bidding. A seven-manager underwriting group headed by First Boston made the winning bid and then offered the stock for sale publicly at $21.25 a share -- 37 1/2 cents above the close yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 14 -- You can always find a caddie among the students at Rutgers University. With books under his arm instead of a golf bag over his shoulder, he will be one of the 53 young men now enrolled at the university through a special golf scholarship.

NEWARK, Nov. 14 -- A motion to enjoin the Westfield Board of Education from conducting its traditional Christmas pageant, rehearsals for the pageant or other religious services in the Westfield public schools was presented to Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel and Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred for 80 minutes today, and officials on both sides said afterward that while there was a need for a new diplomatic effort for a Middle East settlement, there were no immediate plans to set one in motion.

The body of a 19-year-old college girl from Hackensack has been found in a closet, nailed shut, in an abandoned house in the Roxbury section of Boston. The police said yesterday that the girl, Ellen Ann Reich, 19 years old, an Emerson College sophomore who was last seen Thursday morning, had been strangled and stabbed several times.

The Dow-Jones industrial stock average achieved one of Wall Street's long-sought goals yesterday by finishing above 1,000 for the first time. The venerable Dow broke through the barrier with a flourish, climbing 6.09 points to 1,003.16.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 -- The Mexican Equestrian Team, which has been watching its rivals pile up victories all through the fall indoor circuit, finally scored a triumph of its own tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The defense rested its case today in the bribery trial of former Senator Daniel B. Brewster. Its final witness labeled the Government's key witness "a liar, a thief, a forger and a con man of extreme capability."

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- An authoritative Western diplomatic source reported today that just over a week before the Palestinian attack at the Munich Olympics in September, Israel and Egypt had accepted a plan for direct, secret contacts to open negotiations.
The recent collision between two Chicago commuter trains which took 44 lives raises chilling questions about the state of railroad safety in this country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 -- South Vietnam's chief delegate to the peace talks, Pham Dang Lam, left Saigon for Paris today, as the secret negotiations between North Vietnam and the United States appeared about to resume there.

PARIS, NOV. 14 -- An authoritative Western diplomatic source reported today that just over a week before the Palestinian attack at the Munich Olympics in September, Israel and Egypt had accepted a plan for direct, secret contacts to open negotiations.

I refer to a Nov. 10 letter entitled "Food for Bangladesh" by Professors Dorfman and Revelle of Harvard University. The two professors refer to the "unaccountable complacency of the United Nations mission that supervises food imports and distribution"

LONDON -- There are widespread expectations of a readjustment of United States relations with West Europe and NATO during President Nixon's second term. His first term saw fruition of basic trends already discernible on the world horizon. These now require policy recognition.

Lee Trevino, the talkative Texan, who has won $214,805 playing tournament golf this year, has been fined $850 for his withdrawal from last month's Sahara tournament at Las Vegas, Nev., and for his "criticism of tourney officials."

ST. PAUL, Nov. 14 (UPI) -Keith Christiansen, George Konik and Fred Speck scored in the closing moments tonight to rally the Minnesota Fighting Saints to a 5-3 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders in the W.H.A.
SOUTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 14 -- An elderly maintenance man was shot to death this morning, and nearly $70,000 was taken by two holdup men at the National Bank of New Jersey here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The reaction of the two political parties to the election results is a little odd if not downright funny. George McGovern is insisting on the status quo, as if he had won, and President Nixon is shaking up his winning team, as if he had lost.

Only two days before the annual ski show is scheduled to open at the New York Coliseum, Orvil Slutzky, general manager of the Hunter Mountain ski center in New York's northern Catskills yesterday found himself standing in eight inches of natural snow in front of his base lodge -- with problems.

BURLINGTON, N. C., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Two masked bandits, trapped in a bank they were robbing, took a man and four women hostages tonight and drove around on country roads apparently seeking a plane to hijack before policemen captured them after a gun battle on an interstate highway.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -The computerized Bay Area Rapid Transit system, criticized as unsafe in a legislative analyst's report, will be fully operative on schedule for its cross-bay service next September, the transit district's directors were told at an emergency meeting yesterday.
CAIRO, Nov. 14 -- A Coptic Christian church has been burned in a suburb of Cairo in a new outbreak of communal strife between Moslems and Copts.

The American Bible Society presents an annual benefit concert, and sometimes it takes a chance on a conductor new to these parts. The debuting conductor takes a chance, too, since he has to work with unfamiliar ensembles and make do with limited rehearsal time.

If you think the old-time car-hopping of the United States Auto Club was chaotic, wait till you see the finale of the Camel GT series this weekend at Daytona, Fla. After a few ludicrous fiascos in 1967 and 1968, USAC tightened its rules to prohibit a driver from taking over someone else's car for the purpose of winning points.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Thomas Scallen and Lyman Walters, officials of the Vancouver Canucks of the National Hockey League, were committed for trial today on charges of issuing a false stock prospectus. Scallen is also charged with theft.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Winnipeg Jets gained the most one-sided triumph in the new World Hockey Association tonight, crushing the Los Angeles Sharks, 8-0.
TRENTON, Nov. 14 -- A Superior Court judge ruled today that people who solicit realestate sales by telephone in New Jersey must be licensed by the state.

An upstate school teacher had a constitutional right to refuse to participate in the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag in her classroom, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals ruled unanimously here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -Senator William Proxmire, quoting a phrase used by President Nixon in a different context, asserted today that the Administration's wage-price controls program might make businessmen into "soft, spoiled and eventually very weak individuals."

RICHMOND, Nov. 14 (AP) -Billy Cunningham scored 35 points and snared 11 rebounds to power the Carolina Cougars to a 127-118 American Basketball Association victory over the Virginia Squires tonight. Cunningham also stole the ball five times and blocked two shots.
The Board of Standards and Appeals approved unanimously yesterday a plan to build an $11-million, 21story public sports center between Canal and Grand Streets in Lower Manhattan.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 14 -The Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao held their fifth weekly negotiating session today. Although there was some discussion of a five-point settlement plan, the meeting seemed devoted mostly to propaganda.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- James J. Needham, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, announced plans today for a Soviet delegation to visit New York next year to discuss means of financing expansion of Soviet-American trade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -Total business inventories rose more in the third quarter than in the second despite a dip in inventory growth in September, the Department of Commerce reported today.

An unusual sort of night school is going on once a week at The Reapers salon at 847 Lexington Avenue. Peter Lamas and Marc Abitbol are teaching women and men how to blow-dry their own hair, for a fee of $2 per lesson.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -A public health researcher reported here today that periods of economic instability have been responsible for fluctuations in infant mortality rates.

Three hour-long specials in succession are due tonight, starting at 8, over the American Broadcasting Company network. The first, is best -a Jacques Cousteau documentary on the Arctic walrus, which opens his series for the season.

" Arise, Sir Douglas," said Queen Elizabeth II to Douglas Nicholls as she tapped his shoulder with a sword in a ceremony at Buckingham Palace. And as Sir Douglas arose, he was the first Australian aborigine to receive British knighthood.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city's relief rolls had shown a net gain of only 392 persons this September, compared with a rise of 8,845 in September, 1971.

NEWARK, Nov. 14 -- Leaders of the Italian community in the North Ward have asked Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist leader, to let them take over sponsorship of the proposed Kawaida Towers high-rise project.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation, the well-modulated voice of London, celebrated its 50th anniversary today with its past wrapped in glory but with its future clouded by uncertainty.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -Two legislative leaders who held opposing views during the debate on Governor Cahill's proposed tax reform package found themselves agreeing today that any chance for tax reform next year is dead.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- Former President Juan D. Peron arrived here from Madrid this afternoon on the first leg of a longplanned voyage that is to take him back to Argentina after 17 years in exile.

The Suburban Action Institute announced yesterday that it had acquired options on 600 acres of undeveloped land in Lewisboro, N.Y., and planned to build a 4,600-unit "new community" that would triple the population of that northern Westchester County town.

Speak yourselves to the Queen of England to prevent as much as you can my removal."

At some point this fall in the United Nations General Assembly, the United States will have a chance to vote for a plan by which the world's scholars and scientists can unite their intellectual resources on a world scale to carry out sustained research on some of the most urgent problems facing mankind.

In a small office at Canarsie High School the other afternoon, Larry Kieves and Diane Nowlin of the Mayor's Education Task Force sat down with teachers who have been trying for six years to unravel the red tape around their proposed football field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Government filed suit today against the State of Missouri, alleging that it had violated wage controls by paying the state's judges salary increases ranging from 19 to 52 per cent.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Jerry West poured in 15 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter tonight, rallying the Los Angeles Lakers to a 95-92 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

FORT ORD, Calif., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A military jury found Pvt. Billy Dean Smith, the first soldier brought to trial in the United States in a "fragging" incident, not guilty today of charges that he killed two officers with a grenade in Vietnam.
I have read with interest the article in The Times of Nov. 4 giving an outline of the proposed housing project for the Inwood section of Manhattan.

In an early post - election economic forecast, Albert H. Cox Jr., chief economist of Lionel D. Edie Co., Inc., predicted yesterday that President Nixon's landslide victory makes it likely that there will be more effective control over Federal spending in the coming 18 months.
Furious purchases of corporate bonds sent this sector of the credit markets racing ahead again yesterday, driving interest rates down by substantial amounts.
An international track and field tour, with Jim Ryun, Bob Seagren, Randy Matson, Lee Evans and Richmond Flowers in the line-up, was announced yesterday.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 14 -The final-period collapse -- so total and pervasive throughout the team -- continued tonight for the Islanders. They returned to the Nassau Coliseum to find that nothing had changed as they bowed by 7-2 to the National Hockey League's hottest club, the Montreal Canadiens.

Ned Rorem has written many fine songs -- probably more than any other American composer -- and his latest addition to the canon, "The Last Poems of Wallace Stevens," had its premiere Monday night at the David Ensemble concert in Town Hall.

Efforts to restrict the activities of United States multinational companies came under strong attack yesterday by business executives, scholars and government leaders attending the 59th National Foreign Trade Convention.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- The State Board of Regents proposed a sweeping change today in the system of aid for public schools to provide more funds for districts that have neared the limits of their taxing ability while limiting spending by wealthier ones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- As the Navy was completing disciplinary action against rebellious crewmen from the carrier U.S.S. Constellation, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. warned young enlisted men today that strict discipline would not be sacrificed as a price for liberalized reforms.
PLAINFIELD, Nov. 14 -- A 15 per cent decrease in serious crimes here during the first 10 months of the year was reported last night by the Chief of Police, Patrick B. McColgan.
Sixteen physicians and scientists who have made major contributions to advances in the chemical treatment of cancer were named yesterday as winners of the 1972 Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- During a brief period last fall the dust content of the northern stratosphere appears to have increased some two and a half times for unknown reasons.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that its application to open a representative banking office in Moscow has been approved by Soviet authorities. It will mark, when opened, the first representation of an American bank in the Soviet Union since the nineteen twenties.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The impact of Soviet and Chinese purchases of American wheat is being eyed anxiously by relief organizations worried about higher prices, bottlenecks in shipping and the possibility of dwindling reserves in 1975.
GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- The underdeveloped nations clashed with the richer countries at a conference today that set up a tentative schedule for negotiations to liberalize world trade.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 15 -- It took Bill Melchionni a period and a half tonight to work out the kinks in the New York Nets' offense, but then, with George Carter pulling the rope taut, the Nets stopped the Eastern Division-leading Carolina Cougars 112-107.

NEWTON, Nov. 15 -- Telephone service to the state police station here and to about 20,000 other subscribers of the United Telephone Company throughout Sussex County was partly curtailed today. Mayor Lindsay received recommendations yesterday for pay increases totaling $3.8-million a year for 2,619 city executives and judges. A spokesman for the Mayor said the recommendations were being studied.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The extraordinary events at the Bertle household began innocently enough several years ago when Martha Bertle gave her husband, Ted, an electric razor.

A combination offering of 220,000 common shares of the Edington Oil Company at $21 a share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Dean Witter Co. WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, who enthusiastically backed John V. Lindsay for Mayor of New York in 1965 and 1969, indicated his support today for the election of a fusion, or coalition, Mayor next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Members of Congress are traveling to places like the Sudan, Ethiopia, the Phillippines and Greece on "official business." Some people would call the trips "junkets."

The season's fourth performance of "Die Zauberflote" at the Metropolitan Opera brought Nico Castel into the cast for his first portrayal here of Monostatos. A fund-raising campaign that has brought in $1-million will save New York University's Graduate School of Social Work, the university's president, Dr. James M. Hester, announced, yeesterday.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, NOW 16 -- Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos, was placed under siege by strong Communist forces this week, but the inhabitants are accepting the situation casually.

Ten high-ranking police officials -- inspectors and deputy inspectors -- have been told they lack the leadership qualities required for their rank and should retire from the department or face demotion.

An employe described by the police as disgruntled over his work assignments at the Gimbels Department Store warehouse annex in Long Island City, Queens, was accused of shooting and killing his immediate superior there yesterday and of critically wounding a supervisor.

A Queens grand jury has found no evidence linking a 17-year-old Baruch College freshman with the rape of three women and an attempted sexual assault on another, District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell announced yesterday.

The Campbell Soup Company yesterday reported record sales and earnings in the fiscal quarter ended Oct. 29, with gains of 19.4 per cent and 60 per cent, respectively, from last year, when the company had an unusual product recall.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The North Vietnamese delegation to the Vietnam peace talks said today that Le Duc Tho would arrive here tomorrow for further private talks with Henry A. Kissinger but would not discuss any modification of the substance of their draft agreement on a cease-fire in the war.

The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it had decided to get out of the aluminum business. It also said that it plans to get rid of "certain chemical and defense-related ordnance facilities," although it would not elaborate.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Board of Education, rushing to meet a court-ordered timetable, adopted a short-term plan today to reshape Boston's school districts and reduce racial imbalance.

The Seattle SuperSonics have been fined $10,000 and their first-round draft choice in 1973 has been awarded to Philadelphia for having violated National Basketball Association regulations in the signing of John Brisker, a star forward in the American Basketball Association until this year.
Soybean futures dropped yesterday for technical reasons. They have been setting life-of-contract highs recently and thus might be considered due for a reaction.

Stan Smith, an Army specialist fourth-class at the time, and his teammates were paid $4,200 each for defending the Davis Cup last month in Rumania.

Fieger, struck me as a failure of interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers asked the Swiss Ambassador today to inform Cuba that the United States was willing to take any steps, including direct negotiations, to obtain an agreement to halt the hijacking of airliners to Havana.

A program whereby pupils in parochial and private schools could take certain courses in public schools was proposed yesterday by the State Board of Regents, which made public its projected 1973-74 budget of $3-billion.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- A 4-year-old girl who was kidnapped from her mother's arms in a Paris street yesterday was recovered unharmed by the police today. Her 22-year-old uncle was arrested as one of the abductors.
ROME, Friday, Nov. 17 -- Former President Juan D. Peron left here early this morning to return to Argentina for the first time since his regime was overthrown in 1955.

The effort of Acting F.B.I. Director L. Patrick Gray to justify his agents' abortive gunplay in trying to stop the recent aerial hijacking in Florida has been unconvincing. One man was killed and 14 others were arrested yesterday as some 35 narcotics detectives armed with no-knock warrants carried out a series of simultaneous drug raids in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

The chefs and cooks union announced yesterday that it was striking at 80 or more restaurants affiliated with the Restaurant League, but a check disclosed that many of the establishments were operating as usual last night.

Not since enactment of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965 has there been such major change in the Government's medical care program as that provided in the Social Security Bill signed by President Nixon. As there was relatively little public attention to these provisions while the multifaceted bill was going through months of consideration in Congress, special interests were able to exert maximum pressure.
A 24-year-old city patrolman sought in State Supreme Court yesterday to nullify a Police Department ruling that required him to enroll in a departmental program to combat alcoholism.
FREEHOLD, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- A Superior Court judge denied motions today to dismiss the bribery-conspiracy convictions of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants.
Robert I. Postel, who has gained wide publicity as a maverick member of the City Council, said yesterday that he was going to run for Mayor next year.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Meadow Stable's Secretariat may go off as the shortest-price favorite in the 20-year history of the rich Garden State Stakes tomorrow.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13 -- Steady streams of opium and hashish flow over the unpatrolled and porous borders of this landlocked kingdom and through its two airports, aided by a largely indifferent Government and many of its officials and employes.
Three hundred tenants in Mitchell-Lama housing jammed the Board of Estimate Chamber in City Hall yesterday to denounce proposed new regulation of their projects.

NEWBURGH, N. Y. Nov. 17, (UPI) -- The State Police were trying today to unravel a bizarre series of incidents that included a man allegedly being kidnapped, a telephone tip, high-speed chase and the arrest of four persons.

PARIS, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- The Bank of France said today it was raising to 33 per cent the reserve requirement for outstanding credits granted by banks and other financial establishments with effect from Nov. 21.

When Don Parish played for the St. Louis Cardinals as a National Football League rookie two years ago, he was considered a promising outside linebacker. After having been named to various All-America teams and voted the outstanding senior in the Pacific Eight as a Stanford star, Parish became a starter with the Cardinals and was named their rookie of the year.

A high-ranking official from East Germany offered yesterday a long catalog of goods that he thought his country could exchange with the United States. He also implied strongly that East Germany was in no rush to obtain American credits or investments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris on Sunday to resume on Monday negotiations with North Vietnam that the Administration hopes will produce an Indochina settlement within weeks.

Interpol's first list of the world's 12 "most wanted" stolen paintings, a sort of rogue's gallery of art, was made public yesterday to let the public in on the art community's sleuthing and to focus attention on a few of the growing number of stolen works, hopefully to raise the dismally low recovery rate.

NEWARK, Nov. 17 -- Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson scoffed today at reports that he is being pressured to drop the 38-year-old executive director of the city's High Impact Anti-Crime Program because of delays in getting it under way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Former United States Senator Daniel B. Brewster was found guilty today of accepting an unlawful gratuity from a Washington lobbyist to influence his Senate vote on postal rate legislation.

Pepsico, Inc., announced yesterday that, according to preliminary results, it had received in excess of 2.4 million common shares of the Rheingold Corporation, or about 76 per cent of the common shares outstanding, in response to its tender offer.

The tribute to Eleanor Roosevelt by Adlai E. Stevenson (Op-Ed Nov. 7), the tenth anniversary of her death, has reminded me of what I feel sure is an unrecorded example of her courage and compassion to which I was witness.

State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin has dismissed perjury charges against two former detectives indicted in connection with an investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office into murder and possible corruption by officials.

All but one of the 59 teachers at Thomas Jefferson High School Annex returned to work yesterday as parents voiced criticism the walkout on Thursday that dramatized demands by the teachers for more protection against roving youth gangs in the school's East New York area.

About 200 patrons of a Pennsauken bar that featured topless go-go dancers dashed from the place yesterday into the face of television news cameras that were covering a lunchtime raid by the state police. A police spokesman said that 18 persons were arrested, including four dancers, who were charged with lewdness. The others were all part of the management of the bar, the Club Lido, and were charged with aiding and abetting lewdness.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a city budget amended and passed by the Syracuse Common Council is a legal spending plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Central Intelligence Agency's thirst for worldwide intelligence has turned to Peruvian anchovies and a "mysterious" warm current in the Pacific that made the fish disappear this year.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- An all-white jury, ignoring the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court virtually outlawing the death penalty, went beyond a prosecutor's request for a million-year prison sentence yesterday and recommended that a black defendant die in the electric chair.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 -- Juan Domingo Peron returned to Argentina today after 17 years of exile, saying he seeks to unite a country that has been divided since the end of his authoritarian rule.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- One hundred delegates to the New Jersey State League of Municipalities -- mayors, councilmen and municipal officials -- today urged the Legislature to readjust the tax-exempt status of state, county and other publicly owned properties within municipalities to ease local tax burdens.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- In the wake of nearly a year of agitation and rebellion behind prison walls, the Massachusetts Department of Corrections is pushing ahead with a major program of penal reform.
The Coca-Cola Company told its top officers yesterday to be "confident that Coca-Cola as the world's most popular soft drink in due course will be available in the Soviet Union."
Business has been involved with supportive or rehabilitative work with the disabled for some time. This concern has manifested itself in a variety of ways.

HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Julius Erving poured in 45 points and Virginia hit all of its 26 free-throw attempts tonight as the Squires rallied from a 15-point deficit in the second quarter and defeated the Kentucky Colonels, 122-115, in an American Basketball Association game.
The exhibition "Ottocento Painting in American Collections," which opened this week at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, is one of those shows a critic feels duty bound to cover.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- John Z. DeLorean, a General Motors vice president, has warned other executives of the corporation that "poor quality threatens to destroy us" and that warranty repairs now cost the company nearly $500-million a year.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit rejected today a limited agreement offered by Samuel Popkin, a Harvard assistant professor, by which he would answer questions before a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the Pentagon papers.

If Pete Gogolak kicks a field goal Sunday in St. Louis, or three extra points, he will become the highest scorer in the history of the New York Giants.

Two college students and a 16-year-old girl have been arrested and charged with setting fire to an interracial church in Forest Hills, District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 17 -- A Nassau County correction officer was convicted by a County Court jury last night on charges of having received a bribe, official misconduct and promoting prison contraband.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Treasury raised $2-billion with the auction today of 147-day tax-anticipation bills for which bidding appeared quite aggressive. The average rate of discount approximated 4.722 per cent, equivalent to a price of 98.072.

Love was the theme last night at the 1972 Financial Follies but the barbs at the leaders of business, finance and government were as sharp as ever. Appearing before a group of about 1,000 businessmen, brokers, bankers and government officials, members of the New York Financial Writers' Association presented their annual musical parody show of the events of the year in the financial world.
The Olin Corporation sought yesterday to allay the fears of employes of its aluminum group by assuring them that it intends to keep up operations until it can find a buyer.

BATON ROUGE, Nov. 17 -- Two young black men killed in a campus confrontation yesterday were "possibly" shot by a policeman who mistakenly loaded a buckshot shell instead of a tear-gas shell, Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 -- Perhaps half the 25 million Argentines still call a fine sunny day or a lucky day in business or in love "a Peronist's day."

A pilot police project in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn to place luminescent decals on car windows detailing their owners by age, sex and residential area seems promising, a patrolman who started the program said yesterday.

Somewhere out there on the steppes an underground poet may be scrawling the forbidden words, "It's the Real Thing -- Coke Is!" But the Iron Curtain is still down for Coca-Cola now that a deal has been made between the Ministry of Trade and Pepsi-Cola for exclusive bottling and distribution rights in the Soviet Union. The "Pepsi Generation" is about to explode with a fizz from the Ukraine to Siberia.

The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA) yesterday ordered its members at the Columbia Broadcasting System to begin honoring, at 6 P.M. next Tuesday, the picket lines of the network's striking cameramen and other technicians.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Le Duc Tho arrived here today for another round of negotiations with Henry A. Kissinger and said his aim was the rapid conclusion of the "agreement on ending the war and restoring peace in Vietnam."

Two witnesses in a murder trial whose testimony won a holdup man a hung jury in murder trial were arrested yesterday on perjury charges after the man for whom they testified was convicted in his second trial.
Surrealism lives!

My son Keith is a victim of the Vietnam war as surely as if he were missing in action. It is nearly two years since I have seen or heard from him, and when next we shall meet, if ever we do, is problematical. For Keith is one of those numberless young Americans (how many? no one knows) who, caught in the trap of military service, found no answer but desertion.
The over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange finished the week in a bullish fashion as both lists rose in fairly active trading.
A bakery strike and lockout continutd yesterday for the 17th day, with 19 specialty bakers unable to reach an accord with the union representing striking driver-salesmen.

Beginning its 22d consecutive season on the National Broadcasting Company, the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" last night offered "The Hands of Cormac Joyce" as its 100th television production. Adapted by S. S. Schweitzer from a novel by Leonard Wibberly, and directed by Fielder Cook, the story was set in the Aran Islands, off the west coast of Ireland.
Plywood futures prices have been tumbling recently, perhaps because winter is here and construction has slowed, especially in the Middle West where there have been snowstorms.

The arrival of a first-rate Don Giovanni on the scene is rare enough to be worth celebrating, and the Metropolitan Opera is therefore entitled to break out the champagne. The newcomer is Roger Soyer, a rapier-slim French bass who made an impressive debut on Thursday night in the season's seventh "Don Giovanni."

The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company of Pittsburgh, which is Pennsylvania's largest bank, announced yesterday that it would suspend use of the "floating" prime rate should that formula produce a rate in excess of 6 per cent.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- Special British postal security stopped a letter bomb from reaching the House of Commons, Scotland Yard disclosed today.
RHAUNEN, West Germany, -- A wiry, silver-haired candidate in a neat gray suit is talking to a grizzled peasant in a tavern.

Illinois Central Industries yesterday announced that directors had approved a plan to retire 9.5 million common shares, 146,475 of first preferred stock and 22 shares of second preferred stock. The shares are all currently held in the company treasury. They were issued in connection with the merger earlier this year of Illinois Central and Gulf Mobile Ohio Railroads to form Illinois Central Gulf Railroad.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17 -- An official recount completed late today showed that Representative Peter A. Peyser had won re-election in the 23d Congressional District over former Representative Richard L. Ottinger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris on Sunday to resume on Monday negotiations with North Vietnam that the Administration hopes will produce an Indochina settlement within weeks.

Bowl officials have confirmed that if all goes well today matchups for three of the four major postseason bowl games would be Penn State-Oklahoma in the Sugar Bowl, Alabama-Texas in the Cotton Bowl and Nebraska-Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl. A loss by any of these teams today might change things, but all are highly favored.

TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- New Jersey's Board of Higher Education recommended today a 13 per cent increase in spending for the state's institutions of higher learning in fiscal 1974. This year the actual increase was 20 per cent, and the year before, 22 per cent.
The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it had changed its mind and no longer planned to market its own self-developing film for use in Polaroid Corporation cameras.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Ilie Nastase of Rumania played spectacular tennis tonight to beat Jim Connors of Belleville Ill., 6-3, 6-4, for a place in the Dewar Cup indoor final.

It is that time of year again: the new Beaujolais is back. The arrival of this young, partially fermented wine, unheralded two or three years ago, has become another New York "event" and like many others is almost entirely the product of public relations and clever promotion.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Russian State Choir performed the other night in the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London. On the pavement outside there was a counter-performance: Victor Yoran, a Soviet Jew in exile, played works for unaccompanied cello by Bach and Ravel.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 -- Juan Domingo Peron returned to Argentina today after 17 years of exile, saying he seeks to unite a country that has been divided since the end of his authoritarian rule.

When the Orpheon Chorale, founded and conducted by Dino Anagnost, made its debut three years ago, it made a generally favorable impression. In theory, it should have done just as well in its concert in Tully Hall on Thursday night.
As if the New York Islanders don't have enough trouble, the National Hockey League's least successful team has the distinction of welcoming back Bobby Orr tonight.

J., Nov. 17 -- Even though they had dominated the disbanding All-American Football Conference, the Cleveland Browns had to prove themselves all over again when they joined the National Football League in 1950. Robert Coover's "The Kid," which opened officially last night at the American Place Theater, is a play about society's need for heroes. It is a western, indeed, one might say a mythic western. WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Federal officials ordered major restrictions today on the importation into the United States of small turtles. They estimated that about 280,000 persons a year catch a disorder known as salmonellosis from the reptiles.

I.: The former Vice President, his wife and their son and daughter-in-law were relaxing at Caneel Bay's cottage No. 7, overlooking the Caribbean.

Roberto Duran is the world lightweight champion and the uncrowned street-fighting champion of his native Panama City. But he is not the master of Puerto Rico's Esteban DeJesus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Environmental Protection Agency, completing a court-ordered review, has decided not to impose an immediate ban on remaining uses of the pesticides aldrin and dieldrin, an agency official said today.

CHESTER, N. Y. Nov. 17 -- From dawn to dusk today, Eli Garber's horse-drawn wagon creaked westward through rural villages past scores of onlookers who poured out of stores and houses to wish him well on his journey to Pennsylvania.

ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Serving better than he had in recent weeks, Arthur Ashe of New York defeated Mark Cox of Britain, 6-3, 2-6, 7-5, to advance to the final of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tour tournament today.

On a recent weekend, I sat in a circle of two dozen people in a room belonging to a hillside estate whose windows look out on Monterey Bay and Carmel and watched a pretty, dark - haired young woman beat a large red cushion to death. Her long hair streamed down over her flushed, tear-wet cheeks and her slender fists went thump, thump, thump, thump, thump as she pounded the cushion and sobbed.

ROME -- Italians, who have a rich experience in adapting to emergencies, are learning to live without mail service. The red mailboxes at street corners are still emptied occasionally, and the postino (mailman), his heavy bag filled to overflowing, still makes his rounds once in a while.

We were to drive more than 200 miles to the southwestern part of the state to collect some buffalo meat and bring it back for a Thanksgiving feast.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 19 -- Chief Rabbi Shlomo Goren put an abrupt end today to a religious controversy over a brother and sister who have been prevented by a rabbinical court from marrying their fiances.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP) -The Soviet Government has made a change in its emigration law that could affect the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel. UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 19 -- The Nets could have easily dedicated Pennant Night to Billy Melchionni and Brian Taylor tonight. The two backcourt players combined for 52 points and 15 assists in a 118-115 victory over the slipping Kentucky Colonels at the Nassau Coliseum.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- One monstrous mess-up of a field-goal attempt by the St. Louis Cardinals gave the New York Giants their chance today, and after the offense produced the necessary touchdown with 4 minutes, 42 seconds to play, the defense held for downs on the Giant 25 with one minute left to preserve a 13-7 victory.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman today lifted a temporary restraining order in a move that will permit construction to be resumed on the controversial Kawaida Towers apartment building here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Senator George McGovern said today that he would not permit Jean Westwood, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to be "thrown out as a scapegoat" for his defeat.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- The Pennsylvania Legislature completed action today on a strict anti-abortion bill described by Gov. Milton J. Shapp as "unacceptable."

Growing consumer confidence apparently helped four of the five major merchandise chains reporting yesterday to achieve record sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended with October.

The president of the ParentTeacher Association at Meyer Levin Junior High School 285 in East Flatbush proposed a zoning plan last night that she said would increase the black and Puerto Rican enrollment at Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie from 2 to 11 per cent by next fall.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman today lifted a temporary restraining order in a move that will permit construction to be resumed on the controversial Kawaida Towers apartment building here.

The Rapid-American Corporation yesterday elected Isidore A. Becker, the 46-year-old chairman of Schenley Industries, a subsidary, as its president and said it was resuming payment of a cash dividend after 2.5-year hiatus.

Arthur MacKenzie is a puzzling pianist. He can buzz through thickets of difficulty, reeling off scales and arpeggios with great fluency, and yet even at its best his playing stays on the surface. In his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night, Mr. MacKenzie functioned at considerably less than his best much of the time, which made his glibness especially annoying.
Hamilton Bancshares, Inc., a multibank holding company, announced yesterday it had reached an agreement to acquire the Hamilton National Bank of Knoxville, Tenn.
The Columbia Broadcasting System went into State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent its news commentators from honoring picket lines set up Nov. 3 by the network's striking technicians union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The new era of federalism that President Nixon promised in his first term stands a good chance of becoming a reality in his second.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Built-in increases in spending, with no new programs, will increase Federal spending enough in the next fiscal year to produce a $7-billion "full employment" deficit, a Brookings Institution analysis estimated today.

An offering of 675,000 common shares of Revco D. S., Inc., at 46.125 a share was made yesterday by Merrill Lynch and McDonald Co. Of the total 200,000 shares are being sold for the account of the company and 475,000 for the account of certain shareholders. The company's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 46 1/8, up 1/8.

There are moments in Charles S. Holmes's "The Clocks of Columbus: The Literary Career of James Thurber" when you could almost groan. Take, for instance, Professor Holmes's description of "the showpiece" of one of Thurber's collections ("Thurber Country," 1954), a bit of word madness called "Do You Want to Make Something Out of It?"
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange did better than overthe-counter issues yesterday finishing slightly higher on lower volume. Counter stocks declined for the most part.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 20 -- The South Vietnamese Senate voted overwhelmingly today to support President Nguyen Van Thieu's public opposition to the draft peace accord unless all North Vietnamese troops are withdrawn from the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -The Price Commission, in another round of psychological warfare aimed at rising lumber costs, said today that it had begun or scheduled investigations of more than 350 lumber and wood-products companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- "I see where the President is planning to stamp out permissiveness," Senator Moldrin remarked as he cautiously lowered his ancient bones into a chair across the table from Senator Merle Survine.

There was a rush to sell November soybean contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday because the contract was expiring. Speculators apparently were selling out their profitable positions, along with commercial interests who had long positions to settle.
The stock market took a breather yesterday, after its spectacular gain last week when the Dow-Jones industrial average and several other market indicators finished at their best levels in history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -While record numbers of doctors were graduated from American medical schools this year and a new law to create nine Federal medical colleges will further increase enrollments, the national shortage of physicians is expected to worsen.

Two members of the Police Department's citywide anticrime section foiled a holdup of a gypsy cab driver in West Harlem last night, killing one of the suspects and probably wounding the other, the police said.

About 15,000 New York City consumers may escape efault judgments, or at leest contest them, under a civil consent decree announced yesterday by the Government, involving Brand Jewelers, Inc., retailers of jewelry and other merchandise.

Carlton Fisk of the Boston Red Sox was elected rookie of the year in the American League yesterday, and also became the first rookie in the 23-year history of the award to sweep all the votes in the league.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Transportation Department announced today the first successful test in the United States of a magnetic system aimed at producing a floating high-speed train.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A Dacca court today convicted Dr. A. M. Malik, the last governor of East Pakistan, of having waged war against Bangladesh and sentenced him to life in prison. He could have been given the death sentence.

The Newark Board of Education and the Teachers Union start substantive contract talks today across a pay-and-policy gap as forbidding as the one of the 11-week strike of 1971. The agreement then concluded does not run out until the end of January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Office of Education disclosed today that it had asked eight more states to repay a total of $10.2-million in allegedly misspent funds that had been intended for the compensatory education of poor children.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 (Agence France-Presse) -- The United States decision to negotiate with the Cuban Government on "air piracy and similar acts" announced in Washington today has been greeted with "deep satisfaction" in circles close to the Cuban Government, observers said here today.

The Tidal Marine International Corporation, which at one time was a major shipowner, has gotten into deep financial waters -- leaving major banks and pension funds scrambling to collect millions of dollars of overdue debts.

The Michigan Bell Telephone Company auctioned $75-million of long-term debentures yesterday. They were priced to yield investors 7.075 per cent, the lowest level on securities of a Bell System unit in 22 months.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam opened another round of negotiations for a Vietnam cease-fire today.

The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday the cancellation of an order with Combustion Engineering, Inc., for two nuclear steam supply systems. The utility said also that it had postponed plans for building a $700-million nuclear plant on the site in Harford County, Md.

Steve Thompson, the New York Jets' defensive tackle originally believed to have suffered a sprained ankle in Sunday's 28-24 loss to the undefeated Miami Dolphins, was found to have a broken leg yesterday.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill reinstating a program of 13 weeks of extra unemployment benefits to long-term unemployed who recently exhausted their 26 weeks of standard jobless benefits or who did not receive the full 13 weeks of emergency benefits under a temporary compensation program that lapsed earlier this month.

ATHENS, Nov. 20 - Greek university students voted for student organization leaders today for the first time since the 1967 military coup. The vote was held amid demonstrations, boycotts and allegations of election rigging.

HOUSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Neil Cusack of East Tennessee State won the individual championship, but Douglas Brown led Tennessee to the team title today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's cross-country championship.

On the wall across from her, the Miracle Woman, talismans dangling from the hem of her garment, looks inscrutable. The Red Woman tarries on a window seat, Icharus poises triumphantly in the air, and the Old Man, deep in meditation, ignores them all.

The Most Rev. Joseph L. Bernardin, general secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and of the United States Catholic Conference, has been named by Pope Paul VI to be Archbishop of Cincinnati. He succeeds Archbishop Paul F. Leibold, who died last June 1.

A desegregation plan calling for the busing of more than 40,000 black and white schoolchildren in Buffalo was proposed yesterday by the State Department of Education, which has given the Buffalo school board until early next year to react to the plan.

The index will be the first of its kind in the securities industry and will be expected to provide an early-warning system on the speculative tone of the stock market.

The nation's No. 2 steel maker, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced yesterday price increases similar to those made by the United States Steel Corporation last Friday. None of the other major companies has yet joined this round of increases.

Fetsch, the Attorney General's Bureau of Consumer Frauds announced yesterday.

J., Nov. 21 -- Shareholders of Alexander's, Inc., one of the New York area's largest retailers, were told here today that the chain's net income plummeted about 60 per cent in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 21 compared with the year-earlier level. Mayor Lindsay has appointed Francis T. P. Plimpton to the city's Board of Ethics to replace Bruce Bromley, the board's chairman, who has resigned, it was announced yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 21 -- Leonard W. Gilman, southwest regional commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, acknowledged today that he had used his official vehicle to drive three Mexican visitors 150 miles to a Federal prison farm, John S. Alessio, a convict who is described by the Federal authorities as having been close to organized crime.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A Chinese scientist said today that his country was seeking to develop communications satellites, but had no plans for putting men in orbit.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 21 -- The skipper of the aircraft carrier Constellation today told Congressional investigators that he had called off maneuvers at sea and "beached" 137 crew members to avoid open racial rioting and possible sabotage aboard the 81,000-ton warship.
TOKYO, Nov 21 -- The United States and Japan exchanged documents today on Japan's import and production of United States Phantom reconnaissance planes and interceptor fighters.
The Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday won a court fight to prevent its newsmen from following a performers' union order to honor picket lines of the striking technicians' union.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Some see a certain irony in the jailing of Samuel Lewis Popkin, A specialist in Vietnamese village life, he continued to deal with Government experts despite his growing personal opposition to the war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Joseph H. Blatchford, director of Action, will resign effective Dec. 31, a spokesman said today. He may enter the Los Angeles mayoral race.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21 -- The South Vietnamese Government is carrying out a program of political indoctrination and organization in expectation of a cease-fire about the beginning of January. That is the date Government planning seems to assume the shooting will stop and the political struggle will begin.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Chris Evans scored the winning goal with 7:29 left tonight and teammate Mike Murphy connected into an open net with five seconds left in leading the St. Louis Blues to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

Higher housing costs were a major factor in pushing the Consumer Price Index up two-tenths of 1 per cent in the New York metropolitan area last month, the Bureau of Labor statistics reported yesterday.

HONG KONG, Nov. 21 -- For 11 days, a Soviet ship has been riding at anchor in the outer reaches of Hong Kong harbor with a Chinese aboard deported by British authorities here on charges that he spied for the Russians.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Nov. 1 -- When the director of Tashkent's large Pedagogical Institute died a couple of years ago, officials proposed to accord him the honor of burial in the Communist cemetery reserved for outstanding figures.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Jerry Sloan scored a season-high 31 points tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 113-105 victory over the Houston Rockets, their 10th success in the last 12 contests.

There are rock singers and musicians who believe that art is enough, standing unadorned onstage, paying homage to their material as if it were the latest tablet down from the mountain. Not Elton John.

The blue-chip bandwagon continued to roll through Wall Street yesterday, sending the Dow-Jones industrial average to another record high at the close.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Security officials at London's Heathrow Airport said today they had uncovered a racket in airline tickets that was leaving scores of homebound American young people stranded in Britain.

New Yorkers need look no farther than their own fouled beaches and the ominous "dead sea" area off Sandy Hook to appreciate the significance of the international convention to curb the dumping of poisonous wastes at sea which was approved by representatives of 91 nations in London last week.

The University of Delaware, which was undefeated in 10 games this season, was named the winner of the Lambert Cup for the fifth time in a row yesterday. It was the eighth time the Blue Hens had been selected for the honor awarded each college football season to the best team in Division II. Delaware will receive the cup Dec. 7 at the annual Lambert awards luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and Mayor Lindsay released crime statistics yesterday that the Commissioner said showed "people are definitely safer in the streets of New York than they were a year ago."

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The Vietnam cease-fire talks continued today, with no indication of what progress was being made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The White House appeared to confirm today what Governor Rockefeller has been indicating -- that he will not be a Cabinet member in the second Nixon Administration.

HARTFORD, Nov. 21 -- Without a hope that its action would become law, Connecticut's lame-duck Senate voted today to cut the state sales tax from 7 per cent to 6.

Popkin to go to jail rather than disclose his sources, there is considerable disagreement in the academic community over his contention that scholars are entitled to special constitutional protections in their work.

As Ronald Tavel envisions him, Esau was not just "a hairy man," but the Abominable Snowman. "Bigfoot," Tavel's new play now running at Theater Genesis, is his metaphysical musings on the meaning of twindom and the nature of the beast in man.

Now that the Dow-Jones industrials have topped 1,000, what's happening in the over-the-counter market? The national championship won't be at stake but the Big Eight football title will be when those two bitter rivals, Nebraska and Oklahoma, clash in Memorial Stadium at Lincoln, Neb., today before an expected 76,000 fans and several hundred thousands more on national television.

Senator James L. Buckley urged yesterday the appointment of a Presidential commission to study the criminal justice system in Britain and see if some of its procedures could be applied in this country.

Ambient noise is a Carnegie Hall tradition. The rumble of the subway train we have always had with us, and the occasional passing fire engine on West 56th Street. But a new hazard made its debut at the Hungarian State Symphony Orchestra's concert on Tuesday night: a rock band performing in the Carnegie Hall Cinema next door furnished an obbligato of thumps, transmitted by acoustic osmosis.

Pakistan has decided to allow some 10,000 Bengali women and children to return to their homes in response to India's and Bangladesh's decision this week to repatriate about 6,000 members of the families of Pakistani civilians and captured soldiers held in northern India.

Thirteen restaurants and other food establishments are on the Health Services Administration's latest list of places found, after a second inspection, to be violating the Health Code. All face closing or other penalties if the violations are not corrected after a third and final inspection.

Detective Robert Leuci testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had delivered secret information about criminal investigations to Edmund A. Rosner, a lawyer charged with obtaining the confidential documents by bribery.

NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- Lopsided scores can rupture relations in scholastic sports. But Barringer and East Orange High Schools have belted each other freely and have lived to tell about it. On Thanksgiving Day, these schools will meet for the 76th time in the longest, continuous high school football rivalry in New Jersey.
BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Erich Honecker, the Communist leader of East Germany, declared today that "history has already made the decision" in favor of two separate German states rather than a united one.

A genuine holiday treat for young and old -- nothing to do with the Pilgrims -- is on television tonight at 9 over WNET/Channel 13. The program is a stunningly beautiful version of the Ravel-Colette opera - ballet fantasy, "L'Enfant et Les Sortileges" ("The Spellbound Child").

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 22 -- American intelligence officials report that Hanoi has ordered Communist forces in South Vietnam, both Vietcong and North Vietnamese, to observe a cease-fire scrupulously for the first 60 days after it goes into effect and to refrain from all acts of vengeance, assassination and terrorism during that period.
