LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The House of Commons tonight turned down regulations proposed by the Government to implement a 1971 act designed to tighten immigration control.

The Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday obtained a preliminary injunction restraining members of its striking technicians' union from damaging C. B. S. property and from "threatening, intimidating or coercing" C. B. S. employes crossing picket lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Administration officials said today that the chances seemed remote that more than a token international supervisory commission of Canadians, Hungarians, Indonesians and Poles would be in operation at the time of a cease-fire in Vietnam.

Robert Freeman, an associate professor of music at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been named director of the University of Rochester's Eastman School of Music. The 37-year-old conductor, pianist and musicologist succeeds Walter Hendl, who resigned last May.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 -- The Young Socialist Alliance, which says it represents the most radical and best-organized college and high school youth in the country, ended a convention here today, calling for massive peaceful demonstrations in support of changes in American society.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 26 -- After cocktails and a buffet dinner at his official residence in Pretoria one night last week, Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa was asked if the area set aside for the Zulu tribe was sufficiently large, wealthy and developed to be economically viable if it reaches the independence he wants it to attain.

Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino, the former Bronx County Republican leader, announced yesterday that he was returning to active politics and that one of his chief aims would be to oust Senator John D. Calandra, the present G.O.P. leader.

Earl Warren, the former Chief Justice of the United States, urged the Jewish Theological Seminary here yesterday to undertake studies leading to a "disciplined exploration of ethical problems" and the "nature of the good man and the good society."

A consultant concern with $204,167 in city contracts awarded by Ted Gross, the former Youth Services Agency head who resigned recently under fire, was barred yesterday from doing business with the city for five years.

Tonight's Public Broadcasting Service special on "Population Growth and the American Future" has already stirred up its predictable share of controversy. As a filmed report of the President's commission study on population, presented to the President and Congress last spring, the program deals with recommendations for more sex education and more birth control, including the right to abortion in some instances.

JERUSALEM -- One would have imagined that it was the Fast of Tisha B'Av. Few of the Cabinet ministers of Israel wept and wailed so, on the anniversary of the destruction of the Temple, as they did on radio, television and before the eager press of the Jewish State. The tears, however, were not so much of sorrow as of outrage and they were accompanied by all manner of expressions of indignation, amazement and incantations.

HONOLULU, Nov. 28 -Baseball's playing rules committee strongly recommended today that the highest minor leagues experiment next season with the "designated pinch-hitter," who would go to bat for the pitcher without forcing the pitcher out of the game.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 28 -The appointment by President Nixon of a "Kissinger for the cities" was urged today by Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco.

Officers of a union representing employes of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and the head of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were among the officials to whom they had complained of widespread corruption in the service.
NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- Assemblyman Millicent H. Fenwick, Republican of Somerset, was named by Governor Cahill today to be director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

Nearly 10 years ago Nikita S. Khrushchev, then Soviet Premier, met Ernst Neizvestny, a modernist Russian artist, and berated his work publicly. The late Premier said Mr. Neizvestny's art was fit only "to cover urinals with," that "your prospects are nil" and that one work looked as if it had been painted with a donkey's tail.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- Prof. Samuel L. Popkin of Harvard was released from jail today after the Federal Government, in a surprise move, dismissed the grand jury investigating the distribution of the Pentagon papers.

NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- Police Director John L. Reddin lashed out today at the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, the City Council and "self-serving" community leaders who he said had set elements of the city's black and white populations "at each other's throats."
TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- Mayor Lindsay renewed his attack on state governments today, accusing them of keeping American cities "in servitude."

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A 29year-old woman who was beaten on the head with a concrete block by a spurned man friend was left blinded, unable to taste and smell, with impaired hearing and with her powers of concentration and memory severely weakened.

Devotees of German-language theater should be grateful that Aristophanes's satire, "Peace," has been brought rambunctiously alive by Peter Hacks, one of their contemporary playwrights, in "Der Frieden."

Well, there is always the theater. The new Uris Theater is absolutely splendid. It has space and grandeur. It holds 1,800 persons, and from the inside -- it has no outside, for it is tucked away in a basement -- it looks like one of those modern German opera houses.

THURMONT, Md., Nov. 28 -- President Nixon began reshuffling his Cabinet today by nominating Elliot L. Richardson to be Secretary of Defense and Caspar W. Weinberger to succeed Mr. Richardson as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
HARTFORD, Nov. 28 (AP) -Connecticut's bus crisis stalled in the courtroom today, and bus service remained cut off to 150,000 daily passengers in six of the state's major metropolitan areas.

Late in the 1966 season, when the Giants were compiling their poorest record (one victory, 12 losses, one tie), Allie Sherman went on a well-publicized inspection trip of the two best college quarterbacks, Steve Spurrier of Florida and Bob Griese of Purdue, with the idea of drafting one.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Timothy Connors, the New Hampshire Racing Commission chairman, said today all forms of multiple wagering at New Hampshire's horse racing tracks would be banned as of Jan. 1 "to protect the public interest."
MANILA, Nov. 28 (UPI) -President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today he had decided to place the Philippines under martial law after consulting God and receiving "several signs" from Him to act.

Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, said yesterday that an anti-network "climate" in the Federal Government is making it increasingly difficult for the television networks to fulfill their obligations to the public creatively and responsibly.
The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here reversed the contempt conviction of Thomas C. Renaghan, former assistant chief inspector of the city's Police Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Prodded by a 13-year-old Long Island boy who builds and launches model rockets, the Justice Department today accused the manufacturer of illegally raising the price of a paint used by the boy.

NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- When 15 college basketball coaches get together to talk to the press, everyone is delightful, talking about doing this and that, until the season begins, which, for some of them, opens tomorrow.
The embittered relations between Israel and Uganda figured in a court case here yesterday.

Irving Maidman, one of the largest real-estate operators in midtown, found yesterday that several of his properties along West 42d Street that were supposed to be free of sex theaters and film shows were not.

The Paul Taylor Dance Company, which opened a week-long run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, has brought back two old favorites in Mr. Taylor's repertory as well as two potential new favorites that were local premieres.

The nation's airlines are warning travelers that gift packages they carry aboard jetliners this holiday season will be opened for inspection because they fear hijackers may attempt to smuggle weapons aboard concealed in Christmas packages.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 28 -- The aircraft carrier U.S.S. Kitty Hawk returned to her home port here today with crewmen defying orders not to discuss incidents involving racial conflict at sea.
KEARNY, Nov. 28 -Morning traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike was slowed to a crawl between here and Newark today when a crane fell across the eastern part of the roadway.

The agreement recently concluded among the Four Powers, guaranteeing support for the admission into the United Nations of the two Germanys, following closely on the signing of a treaty establishing normal relations between those two political entities, deserves world applause.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- A prosecution witness testified today that fires were "a common occurrence" aboard the aircraft carrier Forrestal prior to the $7.5-million blaze on July 10 that delayed the ship's departure for the Mediterranean by nearly two months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -President Nixon's outgoing budget chief expressed confidence today that the Government would be able to hold this year's spending close to the $250-billion target that President Nixon has set.

DALLAS, Nov. 28 (UPI) -George McGinnis scored 58 points, high in the A.B.A. this season, and paced an Indiana surge early in the overtime that carried the Pacers to a 120-117 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight.

NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- Patrolman Dominick Masi stood in front of a police van watching 300 demonstrators picketing the Kawaida Towers construction site this morning, occasionally saying hello or nodding to some of the marchers.
For the first time, there is a sandwich-vending machine that permits a customer to make a sandwich with choice of bread or roll.

The city began installing 25 new concrete litter baskets in the Times Square area yesterday in what Environmental Protection Administrator Jerome Kretchmer has said he hopes will be the first step in putting 60,000 such containers all over town.

Making forward progress while looking back over your shoulder has always been difficult in any walk of life. For Cliff McClain, the New York Jets running back, the habit is particularly disdainful. He tries hard to avoid it.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., the New York area's largest retailer and operator of stores across the country, reported yesterday to its stockholders that its net earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28 were 16 per cent higher than in the corresponding period a year earlier.

The main card catalogue at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street starts way ahead of the alphabet. The first card is marked with three dots, "* * *," and the last entry is headed "Zyzykin, Michal."

YONKERS, Nov. 28 -- When Yonkers Raceway opens its 1973 season on Jan. 3, the four exactas that had been offered there nightly since Oct. 19, 1967, will be replaced by five quinielas. The switch in the form of wagering was announced today by Timothy J. Rooney, the president of the Westchester County harness racing course, after permission to make the change was given to the raceway by the New York State Harness Racing Commission.

HARTFORD, Nov. 28 -- Connecticut's lame-duck General Assembly voted today to cut the state's sales tax from 7 per cent to 6 per cent. A halfhour after the vote, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill branded the measure financially and politically reckless and said he would veto it, probably tomorrow.
Tape recordings of conversations about cash payments for secret documents were played in Federal Court here yesterday at the bribery trial of Edmund A. Rosner, a New York lawyer.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 -- Army has Navy's goat again in one of the longest and most successful kidnapping capers in the annals of service shenanigans before the traditional football game.

The nation's airlines are warning travelers that gift packages they carry aboard jetliners this holiday season will be opened for inspection because they fear hijackers may attempt to smuggle weapons aboard concealed in Christmas packages.

Simon Schuster said yesterday that it had contracted to publish a book about Martin Bormann and other Nazis after the author, Ladislas Farago, had displayed what one editor called "an enormous quantity of documents" that seemed "very convincing."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 29 -- The United States command reported yesterday that six American fighter - bombers supporting South Vietnamese troops killed at least 19 civilians and wounded 29 in a misdirected attack in the northern part of the country.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 28 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Indian Government announced today that it would release on Friday all 540 Pakistani prisoners of war captured on the western front during last December's war.
Alexander's, Inc., has decided against a plan to keep its five stores in the city open on Sundays during the Christmas shopping season.
NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- Assemblyman Millicent H. Fenwick, Republican of Somerset, was named by Governor Cahill today to be director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

Already appealing a threeyear prison term for a gambling protection scheme, Nicholas Rattenni, an operator of a Yonkers garbage-truck concern, was given a five-year additional sentence yesterday for conspiring to fix a Federal jury.
William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative columnist and editor, said yesterday that he now advocated removing criminal penalties against the use of marijuana.
Controller Abraham D. Beame was accused yesterday of fiscal mismanagement and political favoritism by a Republican City Councilman from State Island.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Dan Sullivan, playing his first major league hockey game, turned away 31 shots for Philadelphia tonight as the last place Blazers defeated the Los Angles Sharks, 4-3, in a World Hockey Association contest.

The New York Nets are going after their eighth straight home-court victory tonight when they face the Utah Stars at Nassau Coliseum. If they win, they will shatter a club record they set in their last game.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 28 -- Rumania's defiant role at Helsinki, where she has disrupted preparatory talks for a European security conference by demanding safeguards for small nations, is causing considerable confusion and embarrassment among her Communist allies.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- An agreement on the unification of Yemen and Southern Yemen into a single state was officially signed here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Nov. 21.

The First National City Bank, which a year ago pioneered the concept of a "floating" prime interest rate on business loans, announced yesterday that it was modifying the formula that it uses to calculate this key interest rate.
The election of Dr. Kenneth C. Rogers as the fifth president of the Stevens Institute of Technology was announced yesterday by the institute's trustees.

A police detective testified yesterday that one of H. Rap Brown's codefendants once told him that a total of six men planned and carried out the robbery of a West 86th Street bar last fall that ended in a shootout with the police. Only Brown and three others are charged with robbery and attempted murder.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday put off at least until next Monday a decision on whether newsmen at the Columbia Broadcasting System should be forced to honor picket lines set up by a striking technicians' union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to remove uncertainties about private placements of securities outside the accounting and registration requirement of public offerings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Prodded by a 13-year-old Long Island boy who builds and launches model rockets, the Justice Department today accused the manufacturer of illegally raising the price of a paint used by the boy.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The American Medical Association's House of Delegates approved today a report calling for a concerted effort by the medical profession to help doctors with alcoholism, drug addiction or other mental problems.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy resumed its rise in October after a dip in September, the Commerce Department reported today.
PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 28 -Two black students were arrested and another turned himself in today in connection with the shooting and wounding of five students at the Central High School here yesterday.
Prices of silver futures contracts jumped more than five cents an ounce for most deliveries yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, Inc.
A bill requiring new stringent fire-safety features in highrise office buildings was voted out yesterday by the City Council Buildings Committee after a two-year study.

The Westvaco Corporation made a sharp recovery in the fourth fiscal quarter with earnings of 61 cents a share matching the 61 cents made in the preceding nine months ended July 31. As a result, the paper, packaging and chemicals producer realized a 161 per cent rise in profits for the year ended Oct. 31 over fiscal 1971, according to its report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird declared today that fewer than 10,000 young men would be drafted in the first half of next year before draft authority expires and the armed forces shift to an all-volunteer basis on July 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- A group of nations favoring forceful international action against terrorism offered a resolution today that not only would condemn such accts but would ask the International Law Commission to draft "with the highest priority" a convention to prevent terrorism.
It took Teddy Brenner, the Garden Boxing Clubs matchmaker, 11 days and $750 in telephone tolls to set up next Monday night's program involving two South Korean boxers.

Commercial Solvents Corporation yesterday said it would apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw the registration statement filed Oct. 5 in connection with a secondary offering of 214,632 common shares. DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, Nov. 28 -- As part of a program on consumerism at the meeting of the Association of National Advertisers here, the Council of Better Business Bureaus gave a report of its progress and unveiled a new public service campaign that should help make more knowledgeable consumers.
The top supervisor of the Police Department's anticorruption drive acknowledged yesterday that the department had been using what he described as "simulated situations" to catch crooked policemen.

Twenty-five persons were arresed on drug charges in Middlesex County in a wide-ranging narcotics raid. WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Federal food programs fail to reach more than half the needy because most are inadequately funded, are surrounded with bureaucratic red tape and are poorly administered, a report released today charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--Caspar W. Weinberger, whose nomination as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare was announced today, told his staff at the Office of Management and Budget yesterday that he would be leaving.
BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Stan Smith overcame a nervous first set tonight and beat Jim Connors in the opening match of the $50,000 Grand Prix masters tennis tournament.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The Winnipeg Jets scored in each period tonight and Ernie Wakely made 28 saves in a 3-0 triumph over the Alberta Oilers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -The United States has circulated at the International Monetary Reform negotiations a paper explaining in detail the view that there should be an "objective test" of when nations should take action to adjust their international balance of payments.
DEPTFORD, Nov. 28 -- An outbreak of deadly hog cholera in the pig farming capital of South Jersey has resulted in the federally sponsored slaughter of 9,400 animals in less than two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird declared today that fewer than 10,000 young men would be drafted in the first half of next year before draft authority expires and the armed forces shift to an all-volunteer basis on July 1.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit said today that it would conduct an extraordinary rehearing of arguments concerning a court - ordered desegregation plan for the Chattanooga, Tenn., public schools.

The National Mediation Board intervened yesterday in the contract dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and 12 nonoperating unions in an effort to avoid a strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

A Suffolk County grand jury indicted the business manager of the Brentwood, L. I., school district yesterday and ordered misdemeanor charges filed against three present or former school board members who allegedly took their spouses to a national school boards convention in San Francisco last April, billing the district for all their traveling expenses.
A 62-year-old Queens man yesterday became the first person arrested in this state, and perhaps in this country, on charges of illegally practicing acupuncture.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The St. Louis Blues took a 3-1 lead in the first period, then held off the Toronto Maple Leafs for a 4-2 National Hockey League victory tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -President Nixon has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to allot to the states only $2-billion of the $5-billion authorized by Congress in the present fiscal year for waste treatment plants, and only $3billion of the $6-billion authorized for the fiscal year 1974.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 29 -- A Japanese airliner crashed last evening shortly after takeoff from Moscow's airport, and 58 of the 75 passengers were reported killed.

That embarrassment of riches currently known as the New York Knicks brushed aside the Cleveland Cavaliers, 107-84, at Madison Square Garden last night, but it took Dick Barnett, a former hero serving as a reserve for a reserve, to electrify a crowd of 16,551 in the final quarter.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The state of West Virginia has gone into the business of selling moonshine.
HONOLULU, Nov. 28 -Frank Robinson and four other players were traded to the California Angels today in a sevenman exchange that sent Andy Messersmith and Ken McMullen to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The Consumers Union, after a five-year study of drugs, has recommended the immediate repeal of all Federal and state laws against marijuana, the establishment of experimental heroin maintenance programs and a nationwide ban on cigarette and alcohol advertising.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 28 -Although the Buffalo Sabres criticized themselves afterward, they impressed a lot of people tonight with a 7-2 thumping of the Islanders and demonstrated a passing game equal to the top squads in the National Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -A New York Stock Exchange member firm called on the Securities and Exchange Commission today to order sweeping reforms in the securities industry.

Seymour Turk, 45, executive vice president of Simon Schuster, Inc., will become president and chief operating officer of the big book publishing house on Jan. 1. Succeeding him will be Richard E. Snyder, 39, director of trade publishing.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 28 -- After two surprisingly scoreless periods, the Vancouver Canucks stunned the New York Rangers with two third-period goals tonight and scored a 2-1 victory.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 28 -- The South Korean Government allowed the nation's universities and colleges to reopen today in a first step toward relaxation of martial-law restrictions.

Stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange yesterday did slightly better than those on the over-the-counter market as volume in both markets expanded.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 28 -- Terrorists of the Irish Republican Army staged their first coordinated series of rocket attacks today on targets throughout Ulster. The rocket attacks and other incidents today claimed a total of four lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today it would delay for two years the effective date for a proposed 95-mile top speed for automobiles and for tire standards for consumers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The California Supreme Court denied without comment today William T. Farr's petition for release from jail under a contempt sentence. Mr. Farr is a reporter for The Los Angeles Times.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends announced today detailed guidelines that will govern payouts by corporations to their stockholders next year.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The life term of a hijacker who gave a rambling speech about the problems of Mexican-Americans from aboard his pirated airplane was reduced today to 20 years by a Federal judge who said he believed the man's sincerity but condemned his method.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The retail cost of foods produced on American farms decreased two-tenths of 1 per cent in October as consumers paid slightly less for beef, the Agriculture Department reported today.

Peter J. Brennan, only hours after being designated Secretary of Labor, said at a hurriedly called news conference yesterday that he hoped that current pay controls could be "phased out" in the months ahead.

LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 29 -- In the fantasy land of Disney, where created lakes and castles form part of a "magic kingdom," Jack Nicklaus will complete a golfing year this week that seems somewhat unreal, too.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Virginia Squires, with nine players scoring in double figures, won their fourth straight game with a 128-117 American Basketball Association victory over the Memphis Tams tonight.

Sew a tent? Or a sleeping bag? Or a down jacket? Until Dale Johnson of Boulder, Colo., founded Frostline, Inc., suppliers of do-it-yourself outdoor equipment kits, six and a half years ago the difficulties of undertaking such a project on a home sewing machine were almost insurmountable.
A 1-cent blue Benjamin Franklin stamp, part of an 1861-66 United States series and considered the rarest regular-issue United States postage stamp, sold here for $27,000 yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- With the kind of alarm the citizens of Lilliput felt over the environmental outrage committed by Gulliver, the British are trying to protect their narrow village streets and hedge-lined roads from the monster European truck.

The state is considering taking over from New York City and all other localities the processing of claims and payments in the Medicaid program for the poor -- a program now forecast to cost $1.99-billion for the state's fiscal year starting next April 1.

After prolonged and at times acrimonious debate, the United Nations Finance Committee faces a crucial vote today on a United States proposal that would reduce this country's share of the regular budget of the world organization.
Dirty linen and garbage pile-ups are in prospect for New Yorkers beginning tomorrow as laundry workers and private trash collectors approach contract expiration deadlines tonight at midnight.

Carmine Tramunti, the reputed boss of one of New York's five Mafia families, was indicted yesterday on three counts of criminal contempt because of what was called his "evasive, equivocal and specious" testimony before a special grand jury investigating organized crime.

"Via Galactica," the space-age musical reported to represent an investment of almost $1-million, is closing its run at the new Uris Theater, 51st Street, west of Broadway, on Saturday after seven performances.

AARHUS, Denmark, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Three Danish rescue helicopters flew through gale force winds over the stormy North Sea today, removed 53 men from a drifting British oil rig and left half of them on a nearby Danish tanker before returning to land with the rest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Nixon Administration and the key tax man in Congress, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, have decided independently that there is no urgency about tax reform in 1973.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Tom Sanders entered the game midway in the second period and rallied the Boston Celtics to a 120-98 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight.
BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- French players again dominated the Queensland grass tennis championships today, knocking out three seeded Australians.

The New York Cosmos, their players scattered from Toronto to Mexico City, announced yesterday that they would return to Hofstra Stadium for the 1973 season and unveiled plans for an extensive season-ticket campaign.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- The nation's first and only fast-breeder nuclear power plant, generally considered to be a $135-million white elephant, is to be closed.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 29 -- The Catholic People's party, the largest in the minority coalition Government, suffered a major defeat in today's general election by losing 7 of its present 35 seats in the lower house of Parliament.
One of man's happiest achievements this year was the creation of a one-acre salt marsh on a small island in Chesapeake Bay.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A military court sentenced the former deputy commander of Military Region II to five years on probation today for the fatal shooting of his army servant.

What could be more festive -- or plain groovier -- than a fast-flying television concert hour of vintage jazz experts headed by such peers as Benny Goodman, Ella Fitzgerald, Count Basie and Duke Ellington? Add about a dozen more "names" and various ensembles and you have "The Big Bands and All That Jazz."

Confessing to a "180-degree change" on decentralization, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark has advised the City Charter Revision Commission to beware of a "simplistic manipulation of the bureaucratic structure" as a hope for improving city government.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 29 -- A researcher whose project on ultrasonic detection of breast cancer was halted when two foundations withdrew their sponsorship of his Federal grant was awarded more than $16-million from the foundations by a county court jury today.

Union democracy has long been a stranger to the United Mine Workers of America. Even in the days when the mine union was a mainstay in bringing industrial democracy to the bastions of the open shop in steel, autos and other mass production industries, the miners' own internal processes were under ironclad dictatorship.

John Newcombe has agreed to play for Australia in the Davis Cup next year. Ken Rosewall has been approached, but is undecided and Rod Laver has not been asked. These developments came about as a result of an announcement by the Esso (Australia) Oil Company that it would put up $30,000 as a contribution toward the Aussies' effort next your to regain the cup.

HONOLULU, Nov. 29 -- In an effort to head off another "devastating" baseball strike, the owners of the 24 major league teams have offered to relax the disputed "reserve clause" for the first time in the game's history.

QUEZON CITY, the Philippines, Nov. 29 -- A draft constitution providing for a parliamentary form of government to be headed for an indefinite initial period by the incumbent President was approved on the third and final reading today by the constitutional convention.

"Ears or the Jungle" has all the makings of a best seller: clumsy writing, dove-tailed plotting, cardboard characters and bullseye topicality. Every best seller must have a hero and a villain, and in his choices Mr. Boulle has shown an unerring instinct. American technology is pitted against woman's intuition -- not one, but two women.
NEWARK, Nov. 29 -- The antagonists in the Kawaida Towers housing dispute marked time again today as neighborhood demonstrators picketed peacefully and construction workers stayed away.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Tom Hayden is as active as ever in the antiwar movement. Julius J. Hoffman, at 77 years of age, is semi-retired, with the status of senior judge of the Federal District Court here. Lee Weiner reports that, as in the days before his brief national prominence, he is engaged in "active obscurity."

The Nixon Administration has decided to issue an emergency rule requiring all of the nation's 531 airports with airline service to provide policemen or other armed guards to help intercept potential hijackers.
DUBLIN, Nov. 29 -- The Irish Government encountered a bitter fight in Parliament today over its bill for wide powers to arrest and convict members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

Ever since General Motors created Ralph Nader as a public figure, more and more people have been getting into the confrontation act. Churches, institutional investors, financial reporters and even business school professors have discovered "relevance," and putting a corporation "up against the wall" has proved easier than trying to understand the complex social-economic-technical issues involved.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the Roman Catholic priest who has served a total of 38 months in prison for antiwar actions, was granted parole today effective Dec. 20, the United States Parole Board announced.

Now that Colorado's voters, by referendum have refused to sanction the financial outlay for the 1976 Winter Olympics that were to be held in the Denver area, the international classic suddenly finds itself without a home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The first round of negotiations on world monetary reform among deputy ministers of the new "Committee of 20" concluded today with no effort made yet to achieve a consensus on the many issues involved.

At Public School 206 in East Harlem, parents contributed the money that is being used to buy basic reading materials and to pay for medicine to treat children infested with lice. The money was raised in a candy sale.

The program Newell Jenkins had made up for his Clarion Concerts in Tully Hall on Tuesday night dwelt to a large extent on concertos of one sort or another. Of prime interest was a new work by Arnold Black, commissioned by the Clarion Music Society and called "Clarion Concerto."

Two leading retail chains, the Dayton-Hudson Corporation,, Minneapolis, and Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., St. Louis, reported yesterday sizable gains in sales for November from the year-earlier month.
Nonoperating employes of the Long Island Rail Road went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, causing a shutdown of the line and forcing its riders to seek alternate means to get to work this morning.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- Edgar B. Speer, who will become the chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Steel Corporation, was described by an associate here today as "a steel man's steel man." His entire working career has been with the company.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 23 -- The words that Koreans, North and South, are proclaiming these days are from the vocabulary of diplomacy and peace -- "reduction of tensions," "improving relations," "sincere negotiations" and "peaceful unification."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- A young man whose wrists were still in casts from a previous suicide attempt jumped to his death yesterday from the Golden Gate Bridge.

Ash to the Office of Management and Budget -- are men of impressive personal attainments. What remains unclear is not their competence but the policies with which they will identify in their new posts.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- The Soviet Government informed the United States Embassy here today that three Americans had been identified among the 60 known dead in yesterday's crash of a Japanese airliner shortly after take-off from the Moscow airport.

Now that Colorado's voters, by referendum have refused to sanction the financial outlay for the 1976 Winter Olympics that were to be held in the Denver area, the international classic suddenly finds itself without a home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Backers of Robert Strauss of Texas for the Democratic Party chairmanship claimed the support today of a majority of the 33 Democratic Governors and Governors-elect who will confer in St. Louis this weekend.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 29 (AP) -Cesar Maniago scored his second straight shutout tonight as the Minnesota North Stars beat the Atlanta Flames, 5-0, to maintain their 1-point hold on first place in the N.H.L. West.

A Federal-state justice coordination task force to improve the use of resources and to integrate policies on prosecutions and sentences in the often-differing Federal and state systems here has been formally proposed by Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein.

Robert L. Vesco, defending charges that he and 41 others had drained $224-million from four mutual funds he controlled, won an initial victory in United States District Court here yesterday.

Two Public Service Commission examiners recommended yesterday a temporary rate increase of $75-million a year for the Consolidated Edison Company. If approved by the commission, monthly utilities bills for customers in New York City and Westchester County would increase by about 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the Roman Catholic priest who has served a total of 38 months in prison for antiwar actions, was granted parole today effective Dec. 20, the United States Parole Board announced.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The life term of a hijacker who gave a rambling speech about the problems of Mexican-Americans from aboard his pirated airplane was reduced today to 20 years by a Federal judge who said he believed the man's sincerity but condemned his method.
The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Southwestern Investment Company for stock valued at more than $62-million.

Yoshio Terasawa, a 41-year-old former Fulbright Scholar at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, has been named president and chief executive officer of Nomura Securities International, Inc. Governor Rockefeller warned last night that the news media's "serious investigative reporting will simply dry up" unless reporters have the right to protect the confidentiality of their sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration took the first step today to develop a Federal flammability standard for upholstered furniture, with a target date of making the standard effective in the latter half of 1974.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was concerned at the imminent departure from the state's judicial system of Supreme Court Justice Bernard S. Meyer, a defeated Democratic-Liberal candidate for the Court of Appeals.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Three women leaped to their deaths today when fire trapped a crowd in a private club atop a 16-story downtown office and apartment building. Eight persons were rescued by helicopters, but it was feared that others may have been caught by the flames.

The directors of the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the election of Edgar B. Speer as chairman and chief executive officer, effective March 1. He succeeds Edwin H. Gott, who will retire at the age of 65 on Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The 93d Congress will have more House members from districts with nearly equal population than any Congress in history, according to a report released today by the Bureau of the Census.

The New York Stock Exchange was reported yesterday to be looking into the trading of shares of American Medical International, Inc., and the role of Oppenheimer Co., a brokerage firm, in the sharp decline of the stock.

A study of 25 educational experiments on which the Ford Foundation spent $30-million has found that "the size of the grant seemed to have little to do with ultimate success" and that the program director was the "most critical" factor in success or failure.

Wheat futures prices continued to rise yesterday, setting some new life-of-contract highs. Again, there was talk of good export demand and the potential of a sizable purchase by India. It is expected that commercial buyers will take heavy deliveries of December delivery wheat to meet commitments.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 -- Gov. Milton J. Shapp vetoed today a bill that opponents said had embodied the "toughest" restrictions on abortions in the nation.
ROME, Nov. 30 -- The Vatican announced today that a hitherto unknown monogram, or secret signature, of Michelangelo had been discovered during work to repair the vandalized Pieta group.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Part of the $1-million ransom paid for the release of Mrs. H. C. Piper Jr. last July was exchanged at banks in Minneapolis, Owatonna and Rochester, Minn., this week, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, spoke hopefully today of the prospect of the reduction of military forces in Europe, saying it was "a natural consequence of the general political activity on the Continent."

NEWARK, Nov. 30 -- Councilman Frank G. Megaro, who presented to the City Council the tax-abatement resolution that was one of the first steps in the construction of the controversial high-rise Kawaida Towers here, now says his political future depends on whether he can help kill the apartment building project.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Israel warned today that if the General Assembly adopted a resolution on the Middle East favoring the Arab nations, the result could be the destruction of the "only agreed basis for United Nations peacemaking."
If the man next to you on the bus pulls out his needlepoint canvas and starts stitching away, don't look surprised. It may be Arthur Kilcup, an advertising man turned needlepoint entrepreneur.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Government backed down today on a proposal to curtail food sales at vending stands operated by blind persons in Federal buildings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota has been nominated to head a Democratic party commission on selection of Vice-Presidential candidates.

Mahler's Symphony No. 2, the stupendous five-movement "Resurrection," can lift a listener out of the here and now in any responsible performance. Played to the hilt, of course, feverishly at times and with the aching longing for lost Romantic innocence that Mahler poured into his greatest works, the "Resurrection" reaches planes inhabited only by a few inspired scores in our musical history.

The rate of growth in the nation's money supply, which has been decelerating this year, speeded up a little in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A Kings County grand jury yesterday indicted a wholesale drug company in Brooklyn on four counts of illegally selling dangerous drugs to an exporter of pharmaceuticals that was not licensed to receive them. Some of the pills involved reportedly wound up in Tokyo.

Glamour issues, market laggards during the blue-chip rally of the last six weeks, took on a bouncier tone yesterday while leading stock averages showed only minor moves.

New Jersey has passed a law to reduce flood damage which is at once so simple and so sensible that one can only wonder why so few states have adopted similar legislation. The bill, approved overwhelmingly by the legislature, would empower the state to limit, in whatever degree necessary, the development and use of lands subject to flooding.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 30 -- Ending a two-day meeting, the 11-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries voiced its support today of Iraq's nationalization of foreign oil operations. Delegates agreed to implement a resolution calling for member states to withhold sales of oil to the Iraq Petroleum Company whose operations in Iraq were nationalized last summer.

An offering of 910,000 common shares of Wells Fargo Co. at $27 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers and Dean Witter Co. The bank holding company's when issued stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 27, up 1/8.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- Recent Communist radio broadcasts have been mentioning the names of members of the National Liberation Front and Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam, apparently in a campaign to make them recognizable figures after a cease-fire, American analysts believe.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Tuberculosis in parts of the body other than the lungs is being seen in heroin addicts, a New York medical researcher reported today.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 30 -- Crewmen from the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Kitty Hawk have told Navy investigators that the ship's captain had an open disagreement with his executive officer after racial violence broke out on the ship while she was at sea six weeks ago.

The Salvation Army Association of New York yesterday presented its 1972 Citation of Merit to Thomas J. Peace Corps of the Hobeau Farm is a steady going, modest money-earner who had gathered together $49,966 this season without winning a race. SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- Political figures inside and outside the Government say that President Nguyen Van Thieu is forging plans for major changes in his Cabinet, based on the conviction that a cease-fire will come to Vietnam soon.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 30 -- India today made her most conciliatory offer in years to improve her strained relations with the United States and with China.

PULLMAN, Wash., Nov. 30 (AP) -- More than two years of research into muscular dystrophy was destroyed when someone released a group of mink affected with the disease, Washington State University scientists reported today.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 30 -- In the distance, the top of the Empire State Building towered above the plateau where North Bergen and Jersey City perch. But here, swaying in a chilling breeze under a gray sky, the brown reeds of the marshes were taller than Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, and slightly thinner. Near the edge of the marshes, a small platform, draped in red, white and blue bunting, had been erected for the dignitaries.

However, he added that he would not "throw the white missionaries out overnight."

Lowery at a ceremony at the Red Cross Auditorium, 150 Amsterdam Avenue. LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Nine Jehovah's Witnesses from Malawi are dying every day in the teeming Sinda Misale refugee camp near the Zambia-Malawi frontier, a Zambian Cabinet member reports. A combination of factors sent agricultural commodity futures prices soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The factors included bad weather, possible crop losses and booming export business.

President Nixon got 1,259,873 votes in New York City and Senator George McGovern 1,342,996, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Technicians at the Apollo 17 launching pad quickened the tempo of preparations today for the nation's final mission to the moon in this decade.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- One of Warren Mattice Anderson's first decisions today as the new majority leader of the State Senate was an easy -- even pleasant one -- to make. It was to forsake the snow, the slush, the grayness and the cold of Albany tomorrow for a respite in Miami, where a conference of national legislative leaders will be held for the rest of the week.
The city's Health Department yesterday named 22 restaurants and other food establishments charged with "serious" violations of the Health Code.

Few developments are so frustrating for a democratic country as a national election that fails to break a serious political stalemate. More than 82 per cent of the voters went to the polls in the Netherlands last week; but the outcome left none of twenty-six competing parties strong enough to form a workable Government on its own or with likely allies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Environmental Protection Agency announced today its long-awaited and overdue proposals to limit the emission of air pollutants from aircraft engines.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Gary Dornhoefer scored a goal in his seventh straight game for the Philadelphia Flyers tonight as the Flyers downed the Minnesota North Stars, 6-2, in an N.H.L. game.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Gerry Meehan and Rene Robert scored two goals each tonight as the Buffalo Sabres ran their home unbeaten streak to 14 games with a 6-1 N.H.L. victory over the Detroit Red Wings. NEWARK, Dec. 7 -- Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has scheduled a news conference for Saturday to name a successor to Police Director John L. Redden, who resigned as a result of the Kawaida Towers housing dispute.

George Bernard Shaw's 70year-old excursion into sexual politics and prophecy, "Don Juan in Hell," will open a four-week engagement at the Palace Theater on Jan. 15. "Don Juan," the rarely performed third act of Shaw's masterwork, "Man and Superman," will star Paul Henreid, Ricardo Montalban, Edward Mulhare and Agnes Moorehead. John Houseman directed, and the producers are Lee Orgel and William J. Griffiths.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 7 -- South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Tran Van Lam, said today that the Saigon Government "would not refuse to do whatever can be done to free the American prisoners of war" and could even agree to release political prisoners in its jails to help bring about an acceptable cease-fire accord.
Corporate bonds held generally steady yesterday in fairly active trading although dealers continued to move out inventories. Governments were quiet and little changed on the day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -The Democratic National Committee's 16-member executive board opened two days of bargaining here today over the party chairmanship and the reforming of last year's reforms.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The United States command announced today that no Americans had been killed in action in Vietnam last week for the second successive week. But it said that three Americans died from noncombat causes, one was missing or had been captured, and seven were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- In a decision that could ignite a major debate about government energy policy, the Federal Power Commission ruled today that it has no jurisdiction over the price of certain synthetic gas provided it is not mixed with natural gas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Supreme Court decided today that people living in racially segregated housing projects can suffer economic and social injury just as can those forced to live outside such projects.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The nations, large and small, are now concentrating on the problems nearest their hearts, their boundaries and their particular regions of the world. This trend is clear, not only in the new and struggling countries, but in the United States, the Soviet Union and China, and it is particularly marked here in Britain.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -Most of the pretrial legal maneuvering in the Pentagon papers case ended today, and, as of now, the trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. is scheduled to start Tuesday.

NEWARK, Dec. 7 -- The air was filled with treble boos as Natalie Costa stepped forward for her curtain call. The Emerson Electric Company has changed the titles of a group of its top management officials, creating what it calls an expanded structure. Wallace R. Dear Lord, we fear they are potential victims for the panacea of Socialism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Trans World Airlines and the machinists union reached tentative agreement today on a new work contract, averting a strike that had been set for midnight.

The article "Diplomacy No Aid for Some at U.N." [Nov. 26] asks why some cooperative buildings are reluctant to sell apartments to foreign diplomats. Although the article gives some minor reasons, it fails to mention the real and -- to me -- justified reason: diplomatic immunity.

With plays by Gorky and O'Neill presently on Broadway, it seems timely to recall that our leading playwright greatly admired the Russian author. I plead for consideration of the sincere conscientious objectors to war. I do not plead for amnesty, which must be hateful to those men who believe in a cause and whose actions draw attention to their convictions. Rather do I plead for their chosen punishment, whether it be exile or jailing, to give them the opportunity to walk in dignity for that in which they truly believe.

A large - scale campaign against shoplifting -- which Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell said cost the borough's retailers $123million last year -- has been started by a civic group that is devoted to preventing crime.

The city's Agency for Child Development has begun efforts to integrate a day-care center in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, attended only by Hasidic Jewish children, to resolve a controversy over its use.

Goose for Christmas is a tradition that has largely disappeared. Let us try to revive it this year, not merely for reasons of nostalgia, but for a change from turkey and because a good roast goose, or better yet a gosling, makes a rich and special meal. A small goose is essential, and it is preferable to cook two of them rather than one huge one for a large crowd.

The Dow-Jones industrial average, which has made a habit lately of marching on to record closing highs, did it again last week. On Thursday the Dow finished at 1,033.26 -- up more than 9 points for the week -- and it ended on Friday by just falling short of a new record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The slayings last month of two students at Southern University in Baton Rouge, La., were a dramatic example of growing student unrest that is shaking the foundations of black colleges throughout the South.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Season's Greetings to all our wonderful friends! And for those who don't believe in seasons, a great big end-of-the year hi!
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The Paris garbagemen went out on strike three days ago and the streets are starting to smell a little in the damp December air.

The Soviets and the Germans, as well as the Western allies, have an appraisal of West Berlin and its future different from the one C. L. Sulzberger expressed in his column in The Times of Nov. 26. The leaders in the Kremlin consider the city important enough to protect in their adherence to the recent four-power agreement. This pact reaffirms more strongly than any statement since 1949 the responsibility which they share for the city.

" Rage," directed and superbly acted by George C. Scott, is based upon a Utah incident of a few years ago when escaped gas resulting from some military exercises at the Dougway Proving Grounds killed a large number of sheep and the military attempted to suppress information related thereto.

" THE GREAT AMERICAN DISASTER" is the name of a small restaurant in the Chelsea district of London whose menu consists entirely of milk shakes and quarter-pound hamburgers. Patronized by overseas visitors and expatriates, it offers a decent approximation of American food to the indecent accompaniment of overamplified music. But more startling than its sound effects or bill of fare is its decor.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- Most of the 16 million people who each year visit Las Vegas as tourists never get to see Las Vegas. They get as far as The Strip, their hotel room, pool, tennis court and golf club, and no matter how they try they cannot miss the gambling casinos nor the extravagant shows in the clubs up and down The Strip.

MODERN hybrid amaryllis are tops for winter bloom. Although a single bulb may seem like a big investment, starting from $5 and up, it will last for years if given the necessary care. As I was about to sample the main dish -- it was the Veal Esposito, and it had been highly recommended -- a clutch of State Supreme Court justices stopped to say hello.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 10 -- Final expense statements show that a total of more than $2.2-million was spent in the race for Governor last month in which Arch A. Moore Jr., the Republican incumbent, defeated Secretary of State John D. Rockefeller 4th, his Democratic challenger.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 10 -- A history and status report on birds introduced in New Jersey by nostalgic immigrants has been prepared by Dr. Charles F. Leck, assistant professor in the Department of Zoology of Rutgers University.
UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 10 -The Memphis Tams made their first appearance of the American Basketball Association in the Nassau Coliseum a memorable one tonight by trouncing the New York Nets, 114-96.

Apollo 17 ends for the foreseeable future the era of intensive American preoccupation with lunar exploration. This country has no firm plans for sending either manned or unmanned rockets to the moon. NASA's lunar planning after Apollo 17 focuses primarily on further study of the rocks Apollo crews have brought back, as well as following the reports radioed back by instruments placed on the moon by astronauts.
CAIRO, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -Egypt's Parliament has made an unprecedented attack on a major policy statement by the Government and questioned the nation's preparedness for war with Israel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The destroyer Warrington, which was damaged by American mines off North Vietnam last July 17, may be scrapped, the Navy said today.

The David and Minnie Berk Foundation, which each year presents the Max Berg Award for achievements in prolonging or improving the quality of human life, found its winners close to home this year and last night honored Mr. Berk and his wife.

The American Academy of Psychoanalysis urged its members yesterday to play a "wider, vital" role in alleviating such urban problems as addiction to drugs, drinking and gambling -- personal and social problems, the academy said, that psychoanalysts have not "fully concentrated upon."
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10 -- An Iranian-Italian archeological team has uncovered in a remote province of southeast Iran what it describes as one of the best-preserved early cities in the world.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 10 -- Four Israeli Jews have been accused of being members of a Syrian espionage and sabotage ring operating in Israel, it was announced here today. The suspects were among 21 people who were rounded up by the police last week.

HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- The area of tomorrow's moon landing is a museum selected to offer a maximum number of revealing exhibits including what scientists hope will prove to be the oldest rocks ever brought into a laboratory.

LA BELLE, Fla. -- I haven't written in quite a while, but I have been waiting to see if things would improve here. I am sorry to say things have changed very little; there is less work here than ever before.

TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 10 (Agence France-Presse) -- Prince Sihanouk, the former Cambodian chief of state, who maintains close relations with Premier Chou En-lai of China, believes that sooner or later "Vietnamese and Laotian patriots will have to return to combat whether they want to or not," after an Indochina cease-fire.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- As the Soviet Union has moved toward improved relations with the West this year, its secret police have mounted a determined campaign of repression against the domestic dissident movement that has left some dissenters feeling weaker, more vulnerable and more on the defensive that at any other time since the mid-nineteen-sixties.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 10 -- On a cold afternoon in Minnesota the Vikings lost their cool in the second half while the Green Bay Packers did not. The result, a 23-7 victory for the Packers, changed the power structure in the National Football League as Green Bay replaced Minnesota as the top team in the Central Division of the National Conference.
